Back in 2015, I saw a huge cardboard display for the new Fantastic Four movie, and I thought, "Oh no, is this gonna be one of those movies where it's coated in that ugly desaturated earth and metal tones?" So, I didn't watch it because I wasn't into Marvel movies in general, but it might be a critical success regardless. However, this movie describing the origins of the team, which includes Mr. Fantastic (Miles Teller), Invisible Girl (Kate Mara), Human Torch (Michael B. Jordan) and Thing (Jamie Bell), and their plot to defeat the evil Dr. Doom (Toby Kebell) had been critically thrashed, warranting a 5% rating on Rotten Tomatoes. Well, after seeing this, part of me can see why, but on the other hand, on the other perspective, it's not exactly worthy of a low rating. The story splits into two segments: Reed Richards building the dimensional transporter and the four superheroes fighting Von Doom. Although the story takes itself way too seriously, most of the movie is shot in the dark, and the most of the action happens in the background, Josh Trank's Fantastic Four is competent on visual effects, the musical score by Marco Beltrami and Philip Glass, and the performances by Teller, Mara, Jordan and Bell. Most of the faults in the movie come from producer and co-writer Simon Kinberg, who wanted to capitalize on the success on The Avengers and X-Men and make a realistic version of Jack Kirby and Stan Lee's story. His obsession with dimming the lights and desaturating every scene makes a chuck of the movie unwatchable and drab. On top of everything else, Trank tweeted that he wanted to be faithful to the source material except with a body count, resulting in a drastic tug of war game between him and Marvel. Despite the messy storyline and blatant studio intervention, Fantastic Four wasn't a good movie, but I'm glad I saw it. (2 ½ Black Hole Sky Portals out of 5)

Let's be upfront, I've never been a fan of the Fantastic Four, but I respect their place in Marvel comics.

I was really bored until they started to Fantastic Four. They spend way too much on establishing nothing, making weird changes to the Storms and Doom, and giving Richards the Spiderman treatment: his thing is that he's literally in the top ten smartest Terrans, but it's more important that he's young.

They actually giving us a more interesting (not hard) origin story, and then went right back to [explicitive deleted] it up again, changing Sue's powers so they don't need the Fantastic Four flying car, and turning them into a military asset instead of a scientific research team. They even took Ben's mechanic abilities away.

They also dehumanize Doom, completing changing who he is, his powers, his motivations, and even his classic look: which cosplayers have shown works in real life, they just had to tweak it.

I'll maintain, pre-disney, there hasn't been a good F4 movie. Eventually we'll see them get introduced to the MCU in some movie, they'll probably buy Stark Tower because the MCU is too broken to have two special towers at the same time.

Although the movie is an adaptation of the previous Fantastic Four it is a unique and updated version. I love the aspect of them not being referred to as "super heroes" because of the storyline. After years of hearing nothing but awful things about this reboot I stayed far away until my interest peaked again when I heard about marvel doing another reboot in a few years so I figured why not check out the would be attempt to keep this franchise going at fox and here we are and I'm happy to report I didn't find this to the abomination that so many people on the web make it out to be. chronicle is one of my favorite superhero flicks ever, the gritty style that trank did with it was so unique at the time and he doesn't stray too far from it here. From the get go it's a very serious and dark film with most of it either taking place in labs or on Planet Zero. This is where most of the criticism takes shape where people argued they didn't get their powers into an hour in but I found the development refreshing, nowadays we are so used to seeing the heroes become their counterparts so quickly we skim over some pretty good material. Seeing Reed and Ben form their friendship in the beginning was great, Sue and him occasionally flirting: hinting at their future relationship. As for Michael B. Jordon I found him to be a great Johnny Storm! Doom of course is in it but barely but when he shows up towards the end man is it awesome, you can tell there Trank was going for something different and the studio clearly didn't support his original vision. I'm sure somewhere on the cutting room floor is a really great film but for the one we got I found it be a compelling small scaled origin story. So Fan4stic the worst of the worst yet I beg to differ.

Fant4stic is an absolute train wreck of a movie. The first half contains some good performances, notably by Michael B Jordan, and some well developed characters, even if it feels dull due to the lack of chemistry. I thought Michael B Jordan done a great job as Human Torch even if he doesn't even use his powers that much. But I actually thought the movie was pretty decent up until the point when they get their powers. And strangely enough, this is supposed to be the turning point of an origin story. When the protagonist (or protagonists) gets their powers it is too be expected that there will be big, explosive and intense action scenes that will ultimately make the film more entertaining. But funnily enough, Fant4stic's script only with holds one action scene, but is horribly contrived by clichÃ (C)s and a really bad villain. From the trailers, this fight looked like it would be a dangerous and emotional confrontation, due to the footage shown in the trailers, but it wasn't! So Fant4stic is the first, and probably only, superhero origin movie where once the heroes suit up, the picture falls into an abyss. 

To be honest, I was actually fairly excited for this film because the trailers looked absolutely amazing but the one clip that got me pumped was the final big action scene that was shown in almost every single trailer and TV spot. The mini clip involves Ben Grimm (more commonly known as the Thing) dropping from an airplane and landing right on a Humvee and destroying it; it conveyed that he's an indestructible rock man and that he is totally unfazed and the clip ended with an extremely badass hero shot, which shows Ben walking towards the camera whilst he is being shot at, however all the bullets bounce off his rocky facade. I loved the design of him, the rock textures looked great and the CGi model looked like how I always envisioned his character to appear like on the big screen. I waited in anticipation throughout the entire runtime for this one action scene to come on, for it too blow everyone away and to level up with Marvel's current standards. But, this sequence wasn't included in the film. In fact, the only action sequence in the film is the boring and anticlimactic final fight which sucks every emotion out of it because these character aren't developed as superheroes because the movie skips through it all. When they get their powers the movie jumps ahead a whole year, where snippets of action segments are only merely seen on TV's, which are being watched by politicians. By the way, there is one character (played by Tim Blake Nelson) who, annoyingly, chews gum in every scene he is featured in for literally no reason, it is cringe worthily dumb. Also, we never see them fully use their powers and the movie never express interest in showing us them. The Four are never utilized as a team before the climax and we never see them use their powers together because for most of the film, between the aftermath of the accident and the climax, there are just uninteresting conversations in dark rooms. 

Did I mention the costume design is extremely bland and Von Doom's make up is laughable bad, Mr Freeze and the Batman suit from Batman and Robin looks masterful when compared to this. The villain is just atrocious in this movie, his arc is extremely messy and he can somehow graphically blow someone's head of. There are scenes with Victor where he is walking down a corridor and he is randomly blowing people's brains out, however, I kind of expected it as the whole movie has a seriously dark tone. And there is not really much else to say except this movie could of been brilliant but wasn't. The CGi is mostly laughable, the villain is disposable and the stakes and violence feel more nonexistent than the chemistry between these characters. I wanted a Fantastic Four movie that included unbelievable action sequences, a great plot and visuals and, from the trailers, it looked like we would get that - even director Josh Trank's vision was to make a brilliant Fantastic Four and this guy can clearly show that he is a great filmmaker. It isn't Josh's fault that this movie is bad, his version would of been great but it's disappointing that the studio cut in. Overall, and unfortunately, we are left with a disastrous movie that crumbles as it progresses, that just wants to make a seriously dark Fantastic Four feature instead of a joyous and enjoyable new superhero blockbuster, but, at best, the film has a few redeeming qualities within the first act and Michael B Jordan's performance isn't half bad but c'mon, B Jordan is one of the best actors working today. Fant4stic isn't the worst comic book movie: Hulk 2003 still holds that record.
All-round clunky, though not as bad as reviews say.

This is a bad movie, but in MY opinion is better than the last Fantastic Four. I believe this is an improvement in the last one but not by much. Michael B. Jordan was an amazing Human Torch. As you know it may not be a comic book like but does that matter that much. Also, it helps to show that Johnny and Susan are not apart of the same biological family. In the old one, it was harder to get that across. As well as loving this one's Human Torch, I also love The Thing. I prefer this character to the old version since its more comic book accurate, more stronger, and his rock texture is super cool. The CGI way is the way to go. I didn't like Kate Mara who played Invisible Girl. I believe she has great acting skills and she had a great opportunity to show it in this film as she goes through Inhuman changes but she doesn't. She says, "I refuse to see this film, it's terrible.". Terrible is a big word for this film. But I won't lie, it's no cinematic masterpiece. Luckily for her, the special effects made up for her effortless acting. Now onto - unfortunately - this Fantastic Fours' Mr. Fantastic is very, very bad. The way he projected his words was great but everything else about him is trash. His facial expressions are bad, his special effects aren't up to standards for 2015, and the actor (Miles Teller) looks way to young for the role.

In this film they show flashbacks of Mr. Fantastic and The Thing as they build the portal for which were they got their abilities from. Miles Teller plays 16 years old him from the flashbacks, which is fine when you add some makeup or some sort of special effect usage. But they didn't make him look the same age in the present. I just didn't like the young Mr. Fantastic. The film wasn't stretched but the timeline was. This film seemed to take place over years and years. Also, there are many plot holes. Stan Lee didn't have a cameo in here. So that sucked. I believe they could of have done better with Doctor Doom abilities because he's quite overpowered. It seemed easy for him to win in seconds. I would not recommend this. I would age this 12 for gore, bad language, and violence.

Grade: B

Easily the worst comic book movie of 2015. One of the worst superhero movies of all time. It's even one of the worst movies in general of all time. Fant4stic is in the top 10 worst superhero movies list. Fant4stic is HORRENDOUS. The team uniforms are super lame and horrendous. They didn't even have the number 4 on their uniforms. The Fantastic Four barely even used their superpowers in this movie. The Thing doesn't even wear pants in this movie. The Human Torch shouldn't  even be black! The movie didn't even get Doctor Doom's real name right. In this movie his real name is Victor Domashev. His name is supposed to be Victor Von Doom, not Victor Domashev! Von Doom is Doctor Doom's last name in the comics. This was the worst live-action version of Doctor Doom, even worse than all of his other live-action incarnations. Toby Kebbell was miscast as Doctor Doom. Doctor Doom was nothing like the real Doctor Doom from the comic books. The CGI is awful. The runtime is too short. The plot makes no sense. The tone is all wrong for this movie. A Fantastic Four film should always be fun, light, bright, colorful, cheerful, and humorous, This movie was the EXACT OPPOSITE of that. Fant4stic was boring, dull, lifeless, joyless, humorless, dark, and gritty. The reshoots were painfully obvious in the editing of this film. The casting is horrible. The four lead actors were all severely miscast in their titular roles. This movie sucks on so many levels. I hope someday Marvel Studios reboots the Fantastic Four so we can get a legit Fantastic Four film for once.

Goodness me, what started full of promise went downhill like a Winter Olympics slalom champion. #FantasticFour fell catastrophically short of fulfilling its namesake resulting in something that's far from fantastic. The story charts dangerous territory from the beginning by messing with a famed and popular origin story, though presenting itself well enough, but even where it was good it somehow contrived to be bad; failing to properly develop all of the characters, stereotyping to save time on explanations, and then inexplicably forcing them into life changing situations only to see them react in ways we don't quite understand given the lack of depth and background provided - not to mention the mad rush to end the film as they seemingly ran out of money. This really was a diabolical attempt at filmmaking, eschewing the necessary aspects required to form a blockbuster. For whatever @marvel 's failings have been with Disney restraining many of the films within the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) to fit their PG-13 covenant, they cannot be faulted for storytelling, character development, representation of source material, and fun factor. Fantastic Four had none of this. A dismal turn, for the third time, surely @marvel has all the ammunition they need to negotiate the title back to their Marvel/Disney coalition and away from Fox. The film simply attempted to do so many good things and failed at nearly all of them, rounding up as many plot lines as possible in too short a time, whilst leaving others dangling but without the proverbial cliffhanger. Poor from, and far from "fantastic".

Strengths: The cast of this movie is mostly strong. When this was announced, I was intrigued by the leading names. Michael B. Jordan (Johnny Storm/Human Torch), Kate Mara (Sue Storm/Invisible Woman), and Miles Teller (Reed Richards/Mister Fantastic) are all great. They aren't at their best here, but they do give a decent effort. 

Weaknesses: Literally everything else. The screenplay is abysmal, giving almost no depth to any of these characters and being so dreary it was nothing like the fun source material. The special effects are almost as bad. Everything looks cheesy and fake. Toby Kebbell (Victor Von Doom/Dr. Doom) was way over the top with his acting and "menacing" stuff. He tried too hard. Like the 2005 Fantastic Four movie, this took way too long to get going. It's nearly an hour before they're even in the alternate world, meaning there's little time for action. And that would be okay if the stuff before they got their powers was even remotely interesting. Instead, it's just dull. It's as if the people behind this had never paid attention to anything Fantastic Four related, because this was missing everything that made that work.

Overall: I thought there was no way this would be worse than the first two Fantastic Four films. The cast was too good for that. Yet, they managed to do it. The production issues are evident as this movie is a total mess. A giant waste of potential.

Ripping the latest Fantastic Four reboot seems to be the sport du jour. While the news about the impending negativity this movie would spark has been circling the media for nearly a year, my inherent fandom of comics in general made this a necessary film for me to see. While not a huge fan of the previous two movies (I've never seen the bootleg from the early 90s), generally speaking, Fantastic Four is a difficult story to interestingly bring to the screen. It's very cosmic in nature, has a long history of some very strange villains and story lines, and can be kind of boring. In the 2005 initial outing, the good things included a very good origin story, representation of Ben Grimm as a pilot and a perfect Johnny Storm. However, Dr. Doom was horrible. Not representative of the comic version at all. Jessica Alba's ethnicity came across strangely as a blonde woman. And, while looking like the very early 60's Thing, the orange suit was...just bad. The second movie, centering around Silver Surfer was a much better representation of the comics, in spite of the weird Galactus. The stories overall were very weak and too goofy. When I heard they were going to reboot it, I was ok with it, for the recasting of Dr. Doom alone. Fast forward to the introduction of Josh Trank as the director. Someone who had done ONE film. Yes, it was a decent film, but given that he was handed the keys to the FF reboot AND a Star Wars film, I was confused. So...fast forward again to nearly a year ago when word came out that the movie was in trouble. Josh was acting erratic. He had destroyed the house he was staying in while shooting in Louisiana. Fox secretly told Disney that Josh would be a bad idea to keep on staff for the Star Wars movie. Then suddenly, Josh was off the Star Wars film while rumors were abound that he had abandoned the final steps in FF post-production. The studio had come in and held reshoots and was completely in control of editing. So much bad press that nearly no one was looking forward to this movie coming out. Marvel was grinning like a cheshire cat wanting to get the rights to making FF back in the House of the Mouse. Then word came that an embargo was being put on all screenings and release of critical reviews until 2 days prior to opening day, always the kiss of death to a film. Then...3 days ago, the embargo broke and the messages were loud and clear. This movie was horrendous. I still planned on seeing the movie, but after Sony destroyed anything interesting about Ghost Rider...twice...I wasn't feeling good. Expectations were in the toilet. So, this morning, as I'm making my way through the surprisingly short (one hour, forty minutes) reboot, I was pleasantly surprised. The acting, even from the kids at the beginning, was very strong. The characters were coming together well. While the origin was different and the inclusion of Franklin Storm, Sr. and a mixed-race Storm clan was...well, unnecessary, it worked. I was buying it. Then they got their powers. From this point forward, it's like a completely different director and/or editor ran the film. There was essentially only ONE action scene. The end. And it lasted mere minutes. Without spoiling what led up to that one action scene, I will simply say that Doom was introduced. A very good Dr. Doom. Character and actor-wise, I very much like this flavor of Fantastic Four. And the tweaked origin introduces the potential for much more cosmic inclusion. The potential is exciting to this comic fanboy. The problem is, from the point where they go their powers, which was on a planet that required CGI and special effects, I was confused as to where the budget went. The effects were some of the worst I've ever seen. Just awful. So many story points were shortened, sped up and left to the viewers interpretation and assumption. Weird considering how well-paced the story had been until this point and how well-developed the characters had been. For the final 40 minutes, character development evaporated. The effects were horrible. There was no story. Just...scenes. Leading up to a very short and shallow action scene. Then...it just ended. A short, quick wrap-up, not to mention dumb, especially considering how strong the film had been the first hour. I simply couldn't understand why the film shifted tone and pace so quickly. As a result, I couldn't give it more than 2 stars. I believe Fox should give the rights back to Marvel or, at the very least, allow this film to have a sequel with a PROVEN director.

This one gets way more hate than it's due, although I do understand people's apathy towards it. I find it at least interesting and noble to offer a "Nolanesque" take of what the Fantastic Four could look like. Most of the film does feel quite centred around Mister Fantastic though, whilst the rest of the cast feels underdeveloped in comparison, almost missing out staples of the FF such as the banterous rivalry between The Thing and the Human Torch which is only seen once briefly near the end of the film. It does feel refreshing not to suffer from the same juvenile MCU Disney humour recent superheroes have been afflicted with though, with once scene during Doctor Doom's battle having me expect a one-liner, which didn't come to fruition. It is however ironic one of the few comicbook characters that eschew this could have gotten away with using it. 
As I say, I like the more real world feel of this one, although that's probably my personal taste coming into play there. Fant4stic Is not a terrible film, if nothing else it kept my attention and fairly invested in the movie. This doesn't mean it's outright a great movie though, in my opinion it is merely fairly alright.

Hailed as one of the worst superhero films ever, it tanked the career of its director (Which also cost him his job as the director of a Star Wars film), was butchered to hell by the studio, and was also a financial flop. Fantastic Four is a pretty run-of-the-mill origins story, but with a darker color palette and is also super serious in tone. Still, despite all the bad reviews, I had enough fun with this version (I greatly prefer it to the 2005 film). It's stupid, poorly written, and the actors are left hanging, but for me, it had just enough camp value to elevate it guilty pleasure status. I liked the action scenes, I liked the interesting nuggets of character development, and it also gave me some good laughs (I love the indifference Reed's teacher has to his dreams and his world-changing technology at a science fair). I sure as hell can't recommend this to other people - only for people have extreme tolerance for stupid, nonsensical action films. I had more fun than I should have, but oh well.

Unfortunately for everyone involved and especially the audience, the creators of this reboot had no idea what the F4 stand for, or what their stories should be about. This is rather dark, without charm or humor and totally ruins one of the greatest villains of Marvel comics. sure, the special effects are decent and there is potential for a somewhat good film here or there but the stereotypes and lack of an intriguing plot entirely ruin any chance of a redeeming movie experience. Very disappointing.

This is one royal mess of a film.  The problems have been well-documented since its release, with director Josh Trank blaming changes made by the studio.  However, my guess is it runs deeper than that as this one seems to be flawed on a basic story level.  Simply put, "Fantastic Four" is one of the least enjoyable comic book movies I've ever seen.  It's not even remotely fun, and I suspect that this was (at least party) by design.
 
To me, this comes off as another attempt to add a real-world dose of grit to characters in which this shouldn't be applied.  There's something that's just kind of inherently silly about the Fantastic Four, and I'm just not sure how seriously we're supposed to take a story in which one character becomes a human rubber band.  I haven't seen the previous "Fantastic Four" films directed by Tim Story, but from what I understand, for all their flaws, they at least understood that.  There's a goofy sense of comic book-inspired fun underlying the proceedings.
 
With this reboot, I'm not even entirely certain the filmmakers set out to make a comic book film at all; it has more of a dark, sci-fi vibe to it, which isn't a bad thing in and of itself.  But if you're going to participate in a bit of genre mashing, you better know what you're doing.  There's not even a perfunctory explanation as to how Reed Richards (Miles Teller), Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell), Sue Storm (Kate Mara), and her brother, Johnny (Michael B. Jordan) acquired their special powers.  They just briefly travel into a dank, ugly dimension and something comes out of the ground there and that's it.  And I have absolutely no idea what happens in the climax, when the four of them square off against Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbel).
 
Please understand, I'm not looking for real-life science accuracy here, or even pseudo-accuracy.  You might recall how I similarly wasn't quite certain as to what was going on during the climax of "Thor: The Dark World" either.  But in that movie, it didn't bother me because at least it was crazy and entertaining, and the rest of the movie had been fun leading up to that too.
 
But in "Fantastic Four," there's no sense of fun whatsoever.  The four "heroes" barely even use their superpowers.  They don't fight bad guys, they don't save innocent civilians, and the only time they even get to work as a unit is in their final confrontation with Doom.  They spend more time under observation in a laboratory than they do out in the world doing superhero stuff.  You can try and explain this away as its an origin story and therefore they had to get expository stuff out of the way first, but I'll still call bullshit as any other origin story will still feature the hero learning to use his/her powers by stopping evildoers.  I didn't turn on a movie entitled "Fantastic Four" to watch four super-powered people not do fantastic things.
 
So we then roll back around to my earlier thought, which is that this isn't supposed to be a superhero movie.  Fine.  Maybe it's not.  But it's still poorly written, no matter what genre it's supposed to be.  There's the problems I mentioned earlier regarding the movie barely touching on some of its science.  But it goes deeper than that.  After they receive their powers, a rift develops between Richards and Grimm, with the latter holding the former responsible for what happened to them.  This rift is never resolved, and by the end of the movie, suddenly it seems like they're cool again.  What exactly happened there?
 
Remember how, after the lukewarm reception to "The Amazing Spider-Man 2," Sony decided to essentially share the character with Marvel Studios in the hopes of bringing him back to his former glory?  I think that's something that 20th Century Fox should consider with the Fantastic Four.  One thing I'm confident of: there's no way in hell Marvel would muck up one of their properties in this way.  This "Fantastic Four" might as well be a DC film, in both tone and quality.  Very, very non-fantastic.

Honestly if I could give this film a lower score I would, but a half star will do since they did technically put something on film. Fantastic Four not only ignores the bright hopeful pop of it's comic roots but also completely neglects what makes the team interesting, it's family dynamic. The scenes with the actors are cold, and lifeless. Everything has a serious tone and almost feels completely robotic even when the scene seems to call for some semblance of emotion. Possibly the worst transgression made by the films creators is taking what should be one of the films bright spots, it's villain, Dr. Doom and turning him to some sort of extra-dimensional eco-terrorist with a school yard crush. Even the designs for the costumes and make up/cgi effects are listless. If this is the best the creators of this film can do with a large budget perhaps it's time to seek a new line of work.

When I first laid eyes on the trailer for the upcoming Fantastic Four movie, I remember loving it, going for a style and tone that is similar to Interstellar. From the initial trailer, it looked like the stakes would be high, and there would be finally a good Fantastic Four film, after three failures. I also remember the dreadful complaints from fanboys about the trailer and their claims that "the movie is going to suck!" Most of the complaints were of the casting of Michael B. Jordan, a black man, as Johnny Storm aka Human Torch, and how this is not a movie from Marvel Studios. My reaction was strong disagreement, as we should be used to characters being portrayed by actors of different color (it is not big deal) and Marvel Studios is not the only production studio capable of making a good superhero movie. I sincerely hoped, and thought that Fantastic Four would be good, proving fans wrong. Not being a fan of Fantastic Four, I hoped that the movie would be good enough that it would get me interested in superhero group and show why I should like them. I especially had confidence because it would be directed by Josh Trank, who directed Chronicle, one of my favorite films of all time for its beautiful use of "found footage" and an unique character driven story that instead of the usual "where did the powers come from?"

Why am I going into how hyped I was for this movie instead of diving right into the review? I wanted to express my great disappointment on how this movie flopped after the great deal of promise it showed. So, what made Fantastic Four the worst reviewed Marvel film of all time? What did Fantastic Four do to have the claim to fame for being worse than Howard the Duck? To summarize the main issue of this film in one statement is difficult, but it would probably be something like that the movie lacked any attachment and cared little for the characters nor the events happening in the world that its trying to establish.

When I describe the lack of attachment and not caring a bit about development, I mean is that film presents itself as this contemporary take on a classic team of superheroes that shows the trials they go through (similar to Christopher Nolan's take in The Dark Knight trilogy), yet there is little stakes shown because all we are shown is secret labs and there is little depth in the relationships between characters. For example, when the five main characters are exposed to the radiation that gave them their powers, Reid runs away from the military base that was holding him and the other Fantastic Four members. In running away, he abandoned his friend, Ben, aka The Thing. There is little to know actual consequences for the abandonment. Ben is angry, but there is nothing the Reid does to redeem himself. At the end, he takes charge when Doom is attacking the planet, but it felt so rushed, so phony. There was no development that led Reid to summoning any kind of courage, nor to prove that he was a loyal team member. Other plot points such as the exaggeration of military that make them look like villains by weaponizing the three super-powered people who remained at the base without any questioning in the story nor consequences or the lack of interaction among the teammates left me feel detached, not really caring for anyone nor anything that is at stake in the story. Yet, with all of the detachment, the film has the nerve to act like that the characters are now a united team that overcame its problems.

To compensate for the lack of investment in development and chemistry, the film uses empty cliches to cue us when there is a supposed development. For example, in the final battle, Ben tells Reid that "this is what I do", referring Ben's battling enemies with his brute strength. The line was supposed to signify his acceptance of his new life and how things will never be the same. The issue is that there is no build up. "This is what I do" is said randomly, came off as out-of-place. A scene or two before, Ben is still upset at Reid. The film never explores the implications of his changed body and how he is forced to work for the military. Another example is the mentioned instance of Reid "taking charge". It's cliche, or least usually used as an effective trope, to cue the audience that the journey to leadership is complete. Films like Guardians of the Galaxy use this trope effectively as the film shows that Peter Quill does truly care for the galaxy, and that someone needs to take leadership because he witnesses his team not getting along. When Quill, aka Starlord, takes the reins, the scene holds weight. When Reid did it here, it was a worthless cliche.

Other complaints that I have are the one that most reviewers addressed. The effects at times were horrendous. At times, the effects looked like they were from Spy Kids 3-D from 2004, which had effects equivalent to the Nintendo 64, a console made 19 years before the Fantastic Four reboot. Obviously the lack of action is a problem, especially when this is a superhero movie. The other complaint is there is little showing of the world around the Fantastic Four. When Doom is destroying it, I wonder why should we care. We never saw it all. We were confined to the labs the entire time.

The actors in general were fine. I believe that issues fell with the horrid writing as I just talked about, the lack of good direction. It appears that one or so takes were done, and not enough time was put into perfecting the delivery of each line. As a result, the dialogue is awkward to watch. Many complain about Toby Kebbell's portrayal as Dr. Doom, but again, I liked his voice. Cliches like Dr. Doom randomly saying he's "doom" are the problem. Bad writing, once again, is the main issue. The film shows no good reason why he became a villain. In my opinion, Kebbell had little to work with. One other positive aspect of the film I found is the deign for The Thing. I liked the natural look of actual rocks instead of the fake costume of the 2005 movie.

I give the 2015 Fantastic Four movie a not fantastic F. Most say the film failed because it tried to be dark, but it came off as depressing, and I disagree. In a previous article, a good movie does not come from focusing on the tone, but on crafting a cohesive story. Fantastic Four obviously botched at creating any kind of story. I can see a good Fantastic Four movie being dark. I'm interested in seeing a new take, but a successful take should rely on tropes of dark movie. A successful movie should show major stakes, and the heroes taking on those stakes, with a plot that makes us care about the heroes. Like most fans, I hope Marvel Studios gets the rights back and does Fantastic Four justice. I hope I can see a great FF team along with the other great heroes of Marvel. It's a shame to see such potential wasted.

There is absolutely nothing good about this movie. The plot is another origin story, which would be fine, if it wasn't awful. With logic being thrown out the window in the first 30 min of the film, while it's trying to be a more "realistic" version of the fantastic 4, it fails miserably. Honestly the first films were better than this one. The acting is awful. The characters are unlikable one-dimensional idiots, although I do not blame the actors for this as I like them all, but the writing was so awful that I think nobody could've portrayed the characters correctly.  A villain whose motivation makes some sense, in the end he's just another villain who wants to destroy the world. This doesn't even work as a superhero movie, because they're only 2 fight scenes in this movie, one in the middle which lasts 30 seconds, and one at the end between the main characters and the main villain which lasts a minute. This movie proved to me that either A) the fantastic 4 are just shitty characters, that's why their movie sucks or B) Fox is so incompetent that they can't make a single good movie with these characters after trying three times.

I simply gave this film 2 stars for what Josh Trank claimed to be a seemingly good script before 20th Century Fox interfered with the picture's production, as a massive Marvel fan, I think of this Fantastic Four adaptation as a weak, useless and demeaning disgrace of a movie with little to no actual plot and a very poor performance from the actors and actresses that starred in it, personally I expected MUCH more from Josh Trank as the director of this film after the massive amounts of success that his film, Chronicle gained. But it was sadly a huge mistake. The saddest part is that when I first saw this film in theaters 2 years ago, I kept trying to force myself to find ways to make Fantasic Four actually a good movie but upon watching it a second time a few weeks later, I came to the conclusion that this film is just completely terrible. So terrible in fact that even the stars of the film don't stand behind it anymore. I never plan to watch this movie again unless it's for the purpose of a "Bad Movie Day". Fantastic Four is a disappointment of a film, and I'm actually more relieved than anything that Fox was smart enough to cancel the two or three sequels they had planned. Seeing as it was solely 20th Century Fox's fault that this film became such a disaster, all I have to say is... Look what you did to such a potentially great movie Fox, you turned it into the equivalent of getting kicked in the testicles with a steel toed boot. Have you learned your lesson about unwanted studio interference? I really hope so.

After the critically acclaimed, dark and interesting semi-'superhero film' Chronicle, Josh Trank was hired for this Fantastic Four Reboot, and he clearly put some really good screenwriting and filmmaking efforts into this. However it seems that the studio decided after 90 or 100 % of the way through filming, that they actually wanted to make this film to be like Avengers Assemble and nothing like Chronicle. There are lots of good Josh Trank scenes left behind, they just don't fit together anymore. The film has possibly the worst pacing of any film ever. On top of this the studio decided to literally name the Dr Doom character "Victor Von Doom". They also seem to have added in an unnecessary big battle with him after the film has essentially already ended- including large amounts of flying debris and a *very original* apocalypse inducing skybeam.

The saddest thing is the complete waste of the acting talent, which is incredible. Michael B. Jordan and Toby Kebbell are excellent in everything, while Miles Teller recently had an impressive breakout performance in Whiplash. Kate Mara and Jamie Bell are also very solid and this is really a group of some of the best young talent in hollywood. And while none of them are bad in this movie, none get the chance to shine. It would have been "fantastic" to see this cast through several sequels drawing from the beloved comic series, but due to a complete and utter studio fumble, this may now never come to pass.

Truly abysmal. Bunch of angsty teens get drunk, decide to explore another "dimension', and then once there to explore glowing green 'goo' instead of running away from it, like sensible people would. They are the equivalent of the horror movie cliches of people running toward danger instead of way from it.  At that point I'm thinking "Darwinism at work" hoping they all die-- cause that was the only way the movie would have been saved. But instead they get superpowers, the "big bad government" takes responsibility for their irresponsible behinds, and all they can do is whine about how their lives have been hijacked. And that's BEFORE the worst of the special effects are revealed in the appearance of "Doom" who inexplicably wants to return to the other "dimension" where he is all alone for no good reason and is willing to kill everyone in his way to get there. At no point is it explained why they don't just let him GO in peace. I would have let the brat do it and good riddance.

Ripping the latest Fantastic Four reboot seems to be the sport du jour. While the news about the impending negativity this movie would spark has been circling the media for nearly a year, my inherent fandom of comics in general made this a necessary film for me to see. While not a huge fan of the previous two movies (I've never seen the bootleg from the early 90s), generally speaking, Fantastic Four is a difficult story to interestingly bring to the screen. It's very cosmic in nature, has a long history of some very strange villains and story lines, and can be kind of boring. In the 2005 initial outing, the good things included a very good origin story, representation of Ben Grimm as a pilot and a perfect Johnny Storm. However, Dr. Doom was horrible. Not representative of the comic version at all. Jessica Alba's ethnicity came across strangely as a blonde woman. And, while looking like the very early 60's Thing, the orange suit was...just bad. The second movie, centering around Silver Surfer was a much better representation of the comics, in spite of the weird Galactus. The stories overall were very weak and too goofy. When I heard they were going to reboot it, I was ok with it, for the recasting of Dr. Doom alone. Fast forward to the introduction of Josh Trank as the director. Someone who had done ONE film. Yes, it was a decent film, but given that he was handed the keys to the FF reboot AND a Star Wars film, I was confused. So...fast forward again to nearly a year ago when word came out that the movie was in trouble. Josh was acting erratic. He had destroyed the house he was staying in while shooting in Louisiana. Fox secretly told Disney that Josh would be a bad idea to keep on staff for the Star Wars movie. Then suddenly, Josh was off the Star Wars film while rumors were abound that he had abandoned the final steps in FF post-production. The studio had come in and held reshoots and was completely in control of editing. So much bad press that nearly no one was looking forward to this movie coming out. Marvel was grinning like a cheshire cat wanting to get the rights to making FF back in the House of the Mouse. Then word came that an embargo was being put on all screenings and release of critical reviews until 2 days prior to opening day, always the kiss of death to a film. Then...3 days ago, the embargo broke and the messages were loud and clear. This movie was horrendous. I still planned on seeing the movie, but after Sony destroyed anything interesting about Ghost Rider...twice...I wasn't feeling good. Expectations were in the toilet. So, this morning, as I'm making my way through the surprisingly short (one hour, forty minutes) reboot, I was pleasantly surprised. The acting, even from the kids at the beginning, was very strong. The characters were coming together well. While the origin was different and the inclusion of Franklin Storm, Sr. and a mixed-race Storm clan was...well, unnecessary, it worked. I was buying it. Then they got their powers. From this point forward, it's like a completely different director and/or editor ran the film. There was essentially only ONE action scene. The end. And it lasted mere minutes. Without spoiling what led up to that one action scene, I will simply say that Doom was introduced. A very good Dr. Doom. Character and actor-wise, I very much like this flavor of Fantastic Four. And the tweaked origin introduces the potential for much more cosmic inclusion. The potential is exciting to this comic fanboy. The problem is, from the point where they go their powers, which was on a planet that required CGI and special effects, I was confused as to where the budget went. The effects were some of the worst I've ever seen. Just awful. So many story points were shortened, sped up and left to the viewers interpretation and assumption. Weird considering how well-paced the story had been until this point and how well-developed the characters had been. For the final 40 minutes, character development evaporated. The effects were horrible. There was no story. Just...scenes. Leading up to a very short and shallow action scene. Then...it just ended. A short, quick wrap-up, not to mention dumb, especially considering how strong the film had been the first hour. I simply couldn't understand why the film shifted tone and pace so quickly. As a result, I couldn't give it more than 2 stars. I believe Fox should give the rights back to Marvel or, at the very least, allow this film to have a sequel with a PROVEN director.

After watching "Captain America: Civil War" I went home as was in the superhero mood. So I decided I would catch up on the superhero movies so I picked "Fantastic Four." And the movie lives up to the negative reception I have been reading. This review should be taken as a warning of what you might see, and you might wanna save your money if you are thinking about renting this. 
  The movie is about Reed Richards (Miles Teller) who is made a  teleporter machine when he is young. His friend Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell) helps him along the way. Eventually, they become teenagers and enter their teleporter in a science fair where they are recognized by Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathey). He invites them to work for him making a teleporter to another dimension. There they meet his son Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), Susan Storm (Kate Mara), and Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell). They make the machine and decide to travel to the other dimension, which is a wasteland with green goo. They get in some trouble and lose Victor Von Doom as they try to escape back to out dimension. When they come back, they find themselves in different rooms with powers.
  The movie is worse than cliché when it comes to superhero films. There's so much wrong here for this to even be mediocre. To me, mediocre is "Man of Steel" or even "Fantastic Four" from 2005. I didn't even really wanna write this but I felt people should know what there getting into. So I will tell you the five things that are wrong with this movie that are not so fantastic.
1.	The movie is way too dark and gritty. This is usually an upgrade when it comes to the superhero genre, but here it's so overly serious it lacks all humor. The fact that Ben (The Thing) got his toughness from his brother who beats him and even gets the phrase "It's clobbering time!" from him is just downright depressing.  Although the small amount of humor we do get is from Johnny (The Human Torch) who is played by Michael B. Jordan. Which is the only character with the character if you get what I mean.
2.	The lack of character development and chemistry is horrible. They all feel cardboard, except for Michael B. Jordan, but the real problem is the relationship between each other. Not once did Susan talk to Ben. They all were separated and only appeared together at the end. There was no real communication or emotions between them. Even when Franklin died, his son Johnny didn't even grieve. After he died that was it. As if they didn't care for him. They are the worst team I have seen in any film.
3.	The villain is Victor Von Doom, who is supposed to be Fantastic Four's biggest enemy. We see him as a human who seems selfish and a jerk and when we see him as a villain in the last 30 minutes he is a joke. His costume isn't scary or believable. He looks like a walking mannequin. He just comes to the conclusion that people invaded his world and they want to destroy it, so that makes him wanna eliminate all life on earth! He is the worst villain I have seen in a movie, seriously he is that bad.
4.	The special effects and action are lacking. The Thing and Planet Zero are the only convincing special effects I have seen. The rest seem very cheap. There is a scene where Mister Fantastic is punching soldiers in the forest and his arms are stretching. It looks laughably fake. 
5.	The action doesn't happen much. Once when the team goes into another dimension, then extremely briefly when Mister Fantastic is running in the woods, and at the end when they battle Dr. Doom. They are very brief and lack to fun thrills. As if they had to cut down on action to make this 100 minutes. The last battle happened so fast, I said to myself "Is that it?". Was Dr. Doom even a threat? Was there even a reason for this movie to be made?" 
  So in conclusion, Fantastic Four is a crappy film and is a disappointment when it comes to superhero movies or any movie for that matter. It seems that this franchise is just not meant to be. Who knows. I can't blame it all on Director Josh Trank. I know on a small scale he is great like when he made "Chronicle". It was probably the large budget and pressure from movie executives. Either way, I suggest you stay away from this one. Almost all other superhero films are better.

This movie was tough to sit through to the end. The first 30 minutes are possibly the most bland, uninteresting 30 minutes of any movie ever made. There is absolutely nothing redeeming about the first half hour of this movie. The reason I give this 1 1/2 stars and almost considered giving it 2 stars is that it definitely had potential. I don't think the choice to give Fantastic Four a darker tone was necessarily a bad idea. The problem was that when the movie tried to be funny it was so cringeworthy, people came away forgetting the movie did at least attempt to mix in some light-heartedness. The chemistry between the actors also hinders any attempt this movie makes in making its characters seem human. Seeing as every actor in this film is critically acclaimed in something else, I believe the blame lies with director Josh Trank. I don't think Josh Trank spends a lot of time around other people because he definitely doesn't know how they talk or how a relationship between two or more people works. It is almost eerie how inhuman these characters act throughout the movie. Anyway, although the movie sucked, there were a few good things I took away from it. The CGI was fine (which kind of worries me as the budget for this film couldn't have been extremely low). Also, and this might be my favorite thing (which is not saying much) about this film, I thought the tone from the lab exploding upon their return/new powers to them in government control (half unconscious/half terrified) was right on the mark. I'm sure people will disagree with me but if the first 30 minutes at all had you emotionally invested in the film, I believe that those dark scenes would have had a much bigger impact and I like knowing that there was at least some vision in this movie. Furthermore, although many had problems with the way Dr. Doom looked, I (not being a fan of the comic) thought he looked much better than his comic version and the scene where he is walking down those hallways bursting peoples' heads open with his mind is honestly pretty cool and you're just lying to yourself if you didn't think so too. Unfortunately, the ending of this film takes any promise this film had and completely destroys it with one of the worst endings of any film I've ever seen. It didn't make sense, it felt incredibly forced, and it was so anticlimactic. Why the fuck was Dr Doom randomly limping when they found him? Why the fuck did he want to destroy Earth when he had literally no motivation to do so? Why the fuck does this all-powerful villain get physically outmatched by fucking Reed Richards? While we're at it, who the fuck thought Reed Richards was a good character to begin with? He is in a group of superheroes who are all essentially invincible and his power is that he's stretchy. He's basically fucking Gumby and now I'm just getting angry thinking about how goddamn stupid Reed Richards is. In summation, this movie started off with the worst 30 minutes of any movie ever made, showed moments of promise and intrigue in the middle, and finished with one of the most shoehorned, anticlimactic, illogical endings in film history.

(3.5 stars)
Bewildered as to why this was so harshly treated. Not quite a fantastic four stars but definitely improves on the embarrassing originals. Those begging for the light-hearted, tongue in cheek approach of most other Marvel movies will understandably be disappointed and perhaps rightfully claim it is disloyal to the comics. In my opinion, this serious sci-fi themed reboot works. It fleshes out the origin story and conveys a more humanistic interpretation of the superhero team. Human Torch is no longer an American jock stereotype but remains flawed with naivety while The Thing is developed from simply being the big, dumb comic relief. This 'Fantastic Four' re-imagining also shows that superhero films don't have to be overloaded with action in order to be entertaining. Albeit there is less 'fun' to be had since you do have to wait a while before their powers are used and in the end the conflict with Dr Doom does rely on contrived elements but I can't say I found any particular part dull. I recommend the rest of you ignore the masses, take a break from these standard Marvel/wannabe comedy films and give the new 'Fantastic Four' a chance.

I actually reasonably enjoyed the start of this movie,. As a light sci-fi, it was working well, until around the time they go to the other dimension and it starts to turn back into a superhero movie. Then it kinda lost my interest.
Still, I could see the intent behind much of the screenplay, sometimes it came out well, other times it fell flat. I think the main problem was the pacing. The second and third parts of the movie (after the 'accident') just feel rushed and underwhelming. And Doom was kinda butchered. I could see what they were going for, but again rushed, underdeveloped, and ended up feeling absurd.

Baaaad movie. Let me count the ways in which it was terrible. A Ben Grimm who looked more like someone's badly made high school clay-mation project. A Mr. Fantastic who looked halfway decent, but just came across as too immature to be believable. As decent as the force field effects were, even The Invisible Woman's force field two step hop landing looked "cliche". And a black human torch? Really? What could have passed for a "warm up" conflict with Dr. Doom turned out to be the climax of the whole film. Never mind cliche line after cliche line. There was even a notable appearance of Tim Blake Nelson, yes, of The Incredible Hulk, which could have had some potential had they bothered to connect the two galaxies, since the two characters seemed to have similar interests, but noooo; even that ball they dropped completely. Even the  Save yourself, avoid this one, you'll never see those two hours of your life ever again.

When i saw they were rebooting fantastic four i was cynical as this wasn't under marvel studios licensing. Also the previous two fantastic four films got a bad write up but i actually really enjoyed them, so there was a lot of pressure riding on this film for me. Let me start off by saying this film hardly follows the original plot line for the superheroes. The characters costumes looked cheap and lazy, no iconic matching jumpsuits with the four logo on, the thing was just naked and dr doom looked like a melted candle. The film takes way too long to get going and the climatic battle with dr doom lasts literally only 5 minutes so we couldn't get a feel of doom's evilness. There was no humour added like the banter between the human torch and the thing. This film literally brought nothing to the superhero genre and should be buried and instantly forgotten, a load of tripe.

Perhaps it's the fact that I had low expectation for this film. I didn't hate it, in fact, I was really into it for the first 50 minutes or so. I thought it was a really cool space travel adventure with some interesting ideas, and I felt Josh Trank's confidence and passion through his direction. I liked the cast (I'm a big fan of all 4 leads), and they seemed to be having fun during the first 50 minutes. I understand this was a troubled production and I can see why the majority of people hated it. It completely falls apart in the third act and nothing in the film makes sense (e.g. Why are they doing this inter-dimension travel thing in the first place? Why is earth dying?) I felt that a lot of things were cut out from the original cut, and the studio's interference ultimately killed the film. That said, this is not the worst superhero film ever made. It's not a good movie, but it certainly isn't as awful as everyone says it is. Fant4stic is stupid, clunky, and incomprehensible, but there is a lot of good stuff in it that I kind of had fun time with it. It's not that bad.
It as a little different from the other Fantastic Four film just 10 years earlier, but at the same time it's just another average effort in a now saturated and arguably tiresome genre.

Okay, it's not Hamlet, we get it, but it's not like the reboot of the Fantastic Four (2015) as one reviewer related Warcraft to.  Last I looked Warcraft was a sporting a 27/83 rating vs. FF's 9/19.  Let me state that I'm a WoW fan, but  really didn't know the lore too well or the main characters.  I've seen it twice already and would like to go again.  The problem I see with Warcraft is that the lore has been fleshed out majorly and there is tons of it.  Parallel story lines snake through it on multiple continents and planets.  Lord of the Rings had a lot of characters, but they seemed to going in the same direction.  By the time the Peter Jackson's version screened it had already been attempted as a movie.  Even Leonard Nimoy had done a song about it.  Warcraft is exciting and well paced.  They don't spend time on ten minute fight scenes between two characters and spend it advancing the story instead.  And there is plenty of that to cover.  A lot of these reviewers don't get it.  They are going to say Steel Magnolias and Pretty Woman are better films, no, they are for different audiences.

Skip this one.

After months of hearing how bad this movie sucked, I finally got to chance to sit down and give it a go. It know it will sound like a broken record at this point, but the first 30-40 minutes of this movie are actually pretty darn good. This movie had a fantastic cast (pun intended), and it's a shame when you see how well some of their early scenes played out. There were even a couple of lines that made me chuckle at the beginning. Oh, and while we're on the subject, I thought Toby Kebbell as Pre-Dr. Doom was great. I even had to IMDB him to figure out who the heck he was. I could imagine him as a GoT character for some reason, don't ask why.

The latter half of the movie feels very rushed, and this is where the problem lies. It could have been, at the least, on the level of those Andrew Garfield Spider-man movies had they just fleshed the character's out a little more. The last 30 minutes are so rushed, it reminded me of the pilot for another CW superhero TV series. I can't help but feel all the rumors about FOX meddling with the production are true, because you really have to stretch to make some of the scenes make sense. 

A couple more of my opinions on the movie. 

1. The scene with Doom breaking out of the facility was kick ass. 
2. Final fight was lame city. 
3. I hated The Thing's voice.
4. They needed to give Mara and Teller better lines. Great talent wasted here. 
5. The pre-fantastic versions of Ben and Victor made me hate the fantastic versions even more. These guys are fantastic actors and I've never even heard of them. 
6. Michael B. Jordan as Johnny Storm felt the most like his comic book counterpart for me. Wish he had more scenes.

This film was atrocious. I can't believe how much they dropped the ball on this one... Let me explain the positives/negatives.

Positives:
1. The scene with Reed and Ben as kids was handled okay.

2. Victor von Doom killing people in the hallway looked creepy and not that bad.

3. The cast is trying despite given a terrible script.

4. There is potential because of Josh Trank directing, who did direct Chronicle which is my favourite found footage film.

Negatives:
1. The performances; every character sounds like they are contractually obligated everytime they speak. Nobody feels like a person the acting is very mechanical and dry. Even though the cast is good and I can tell they are trying the things they are saying just don't work and the jokes don't hit!

2. The tone; this film takes itself way too seriously. The jokes (if there are any!) don't hit at all, this film is so uninspired, it makes the previous Fantastic Four movies look good, because at least you kind of laugh at how bad they are but this film takes itself too seriously. Serious tones only work for certain films like The Dark Knight, but it doesn't work here!

3. The villain; what happened!? Victor von Doom is a joke in this film, not only is he weak but he has no motivation. He is just a bad guy and he looks horrible! At least in the 2005 Fantastic Four they atleast got Dr. Doom's costume right, here they attempt to translate him on the big screen but they do it completely wrong! Dr. Doom is one of the most badass villains and they took a complete dump all over him!

4. The final battle is atrocious, this whole film is boring lacking any action. Now we finally get an action scene but it is terrible and forgettable. One punch and Dr. Doom is defeated. No epic showdown, nothing! Good job guys....

Overall:
This might actually be my least favourite comic book film. Don't watch this movie, don't even watch it on Netflix like I did. Poor Josh Trank, he was treated like an animal by 20th Century Fox. I'm just waiting until Fox gives Fantastic Four back to Marvel. All of those positives I listed aren't enough to be redeeming qualities. Absolutely disappointing excuse of a film.

Despite its glowing 9% on Rotten Tomatoes I decided to watch this. While I cannot say it is good, cause it is not, it was not the disaster I was led to believe. There were glimmers of promise in this. The story was fine actually, basically a 100 minute origin story, not confusing and which set up any sequels really well. Generally the special effects were good, and there were a few moments after they had gotten their powers where I found myself enjoying it. The first half was a lot better than the second half. The main problems were the horrible, stilted, dialogue, mainly during the second half of the movie, and two very bad casting choices.  Miles Teller was great in Whiplash, but really miscast in this. He simply doesn't have the weight or projected maturity to carry off the role of Reed Richards. Also, Michael B. Jordan just was not suited to his role as the Human Torch...his comedic timing was horrible. Too bad Chris Evans is now Captain America. His Human Torch in the previous Fantastic Four attempts was the best thing about those movies. Kate Mara was fine, and actually Jamie Bell was really good as Ben Grimm. Anyway, if they are going to attempt a sequel, they need to replace Miles Teller and Michael B. Jordan, and find a writer who knows how to write dialog for these types of superhero movies. Anyway, if you have an afternoon without anything else to do, this is worth watching, otherwise I wouldn't go out of my way.

I really hope someone can crack the code for a solid Fantastic Four film, but obviously not today. Rating: 11

Pre-release negativity notwithstanding, Fant4stic easily surpasses every film before it to reach the dubious distinction of the all-time worst in its genre. Every single aspect of this film works against it, from the origin story that takes up the majority of the run time to the startlingly inept villain to the single two-minute action sequence. Shocked this got such low ratings.  Although it's far from perfect, I liked seeing the less flashy origin story without all the "camp".  I would love to see this Fantastic Four appear in a crossover like the Infinity Gauntlet.

When this movie was announced I was quite excited to see it because the director behind Chronicle had been given the job of bringing a new version of the Fantastic Four to the big screen.  Chronicle was a complete re-imagining of the superhero genre, Josh Trank and writer Max Landis created something cool, new and fresh to the genre and so I was very much hoping the rules learnt in Chronicle would be applied here.  Sadly this was not to be, whether this is down to the absence of Landis or studio meddling is debatable but the film was quite a mess.
The was a substantial set up before we see the Fantastic Four in action which I don't mind if it is done well but I felt the actors weren't quite right for the roles and the dialogue was very messy.  On a positive point I thought the transformation scenes would done quite well and rested more in the body horror genre than the superhero genre.  Well, this is true with the exception of Victor Doom who looked ridiculous, like a failed idea from Doctor Who :o(
The first half of the film was entertaining enough to keep me watching but disappointingly it was once they became the superheroes that I started to lose interest.  The film was leading up to a battle with Doom which took place for 10 mins at the end on another planet and was fairly uneventful, this made the 2nd half of the film even more disappointing and then we have the final line of the movie and the origin of the superhero teams name which was so cringey it made my skin hurt.
To be fair, the Fantastic Four is a difficult concept to bring to the big screen.  The Human Torch and Invisible Woman are fairly simple ideas but the Thing often comes across as looking too cartoon like and Mr Fantastic is just a live action version of Stretch Armstrong.  They need to forget trying to adapt the exact visual concepts from the comic book and reinvent The Thing and Fantastic for the big screen.  Time to hand the rights back to Marvel, hopefully they can fix this mess.

After this movie was universally panned, I held off watching it until it came to home video. The critics were right.

Yet another version of the Fantastic Four, while the early 2000s version wasn't bad, it never really caught on. Let's not talk about the 1990s version. Reed is a high school science wiz who catches the eye of a researcher who brings them in to work for them. The actors are way too old to be roughly high school/college age so that's the first knock. The actor who plays Reed Richards is also miscast as he feels more like a sidekick at best than the eventually leader. Michael B. Jordan is probably the best actor here and is barely used at all. Kate Mara lives up to her moniker as the Invisible Woman since you often forget about her as she is just sitting at computers most of the time. The Thing also just feels like a waste.

It doesn't help that they whole crew isn't brought together until about 1/3 of the way through, then they spend the next 1/3 wondering why they have super powers, then the next 1/3 battling the bad guy who just gets introduced in the last 20 minutes and they finally become a team with 5 seconds to go. It's horribly paced. It'd needed to combine the first two acts into one and make the third act longer. 

There are elements of this movie that could have been good, it needed a better cast and the editing needed to be better. The villain was excellent, but he is only in the film for a few minutes. The dark tone works in spots, but I feel this franchise more than most is generally very cheery and family friendly and they went the dark and gritty which tonally didn't work like it should. A second installment might fix a lot of the issues, but I'm not sure I'd be interested in seeing it at this point barring another major reboot.

Even thought that aspect took over an hour, you still did not feel connected to the characters and it was a long drawn out process.  Once things finally got going there were a couple fun action scenes that were over much to quickly.  It all felt rushed at the end and it was not a fulfilling ending at all. This is my first review of a movie on Rotten Tomatoes.  I watched this movie the next day after watching Captain America: Civil War.  This recently dropped on HBO so I decided to watch the only Marvel movie over the past 16 years I have not watched.  I knew about the harsh reviews of this movie but I wanted to give it a chance.  

I was thoroughly disappointed by this movie.  Put it this way, if Captain America: Civil War is your most favorite pie (mine is French Silk pie) this movie is just the pie crust.  No filling, no remnants of what was there.  Just the crust.  Perhaps there are people out there who love flavorless pie crust.  I don't.  I sat there watching and wishing there was more to this pie than just the crust.  I was waiting and waiting but.....nothing.  Right off the bat people were freaking out about Johnny Storm being black.  That was such a non-issue as Michael B. Jordan is a fine actor (go watch Creed if you haven't already).  Out of the four he did the best acting.  I really enjoyed the Fantastic Four movie in 2005.  It wasn't perfect by any means and the special effects were poor but that cast was far more likable.  I'm sure all of these young actors are good actors but their direction was terrible, especially Jamie Bell's performance of Ben Grimm.  Michael Chiklis was 100x better.  There was nothing redeeming about this movie.  This should have never happened.

It's highly likely that we'll never understand fully just what happened
behind the scenes of Fantastic Four to make it the film it is today.

It's a film that even the most pessimistic of comic book haters,
popcorn disliking, nerd despising, anti-movie fiends couldn't have
predicted the amount of hate thrown its way and the ill will that Josh
Trank's second feature film received upon release.

Box Office receipts were dire, critics tore shreds of a film they
labelled "boring" or "to dark" and many including audiences were
bemused at how this supposed comic book film floated by for near on an
hour of running time to then descend into a chaotic final act of
atrocious CGI and one of modern movie history's most poorly constructed
and underdeveloped villains.

The mystery surrounding Fantastic Four's failure flows from studio
interference, including the studio butchering a rushed re-edit of the
film before release, director Josh Trank's bizarre on set behaviours
and mismanagement of actors and all manner of script writers for hire
coming in and having a go at trying to make something of Trank's
clearly going for bleak re-telling of an already previously mismanaged
franchise (Silver Surfer anyone?). Considering all the hatred and
lacklustre talk surrounding this film, upon reflection on home release,
Fantastic Four isn't actually "that" bad.

It's certainly not a good film, actually it's very far from it but in
2015 there were a lot of seriously bad movies and at least for lack of
a better word, Fantastic Four tried. It's not the usual action set
piece after action set piece comic book film we've grown to know and
love and then grow tired of and Trank and his team clearly had some
decent ideas.

Bursting onto the scene with his found footage Sci-Fi Chronicle, the
once bright career of Trank seems destined to be clouded in controversy
after his efforts here but there are moments of genuine cinematic
quality. The way in which our fantastic team of unsuspecting super
powered humans discover their abilities is effective and the casting
seems mainly on point.

We all know the talents of Whiplash's Miles Teller, Fruitvale Station's
and Creed's Michael B. Jordan and the likes of Jamie Bell, Kate Mara
and Toby Kebbell are no slouches but whoever in the end edited,
constructed and wrote this film killed Fantastic Four's chances to fly
with some of the most poorly designed editing, character development
and plot advancements in recent memory and not once do we feel any real
connection with these people or believe that they share any form of
chemistry whatsoever and the films aforementioned final act is
bewilderingly bad, the only excuse it would have would be the studio's
so called interference.

It's somewhat of a shame we will never get to know just what ruined
this glum and often more dramatically natured Fantastic Four outing
that at the end of the day has nothing even remotely memorable about it
other than the fact it's so downright lacking in energy,
humour/lightness and a seemingly lack of effort.

The cast was there and no doubt willing but due to a raft of seemingly
powerful situations this film ended up being a real non-event,
certainly not as unwatchable in its terribleness that many would've had
us believe, but certainly a messy, sporadically entertaining attempt at
finally making the Fantastic Four a viable big screen staple.

The Good:
Reed and Ben's friendship is sweet and feels genuine. The approach to the scientific side of this movie is interesting, eventhough it wastes too much of the running time. 

The Not-so-Good:
There's a good movie hidden inside this disappoinment, had it not been made solely to keep a copyright from reverting to its original owner. The flow feels dull and boring, and takes too long to get into exciting action. It doesn't really need another reimagined origin story, and should have focused more on the dynamic between the characters. Very underwhelming action scenes, with weak CGI. What a waste of Doom, this is the 2nd time FOX can't get the famous supervillain correctly, this time turning him into a lame weird looking alien instead of the ruthless dictator genius he should have been. Such a waste of talents too, considering the actors are rising star with proven acting chops. Many of the plot developments do not get proper conclusion, making this feels like a giant intro/teaser for a sequel that might or might never happen.

Oh man. This film is bad in almost every way a film can be. 

For starters, it features a wildly unengaging, uneventful, and flat out dull opening 45 minutes that seeks to introduce us to the characters before they gain their superpowers. This segment isn't necessarily horrendously written or poorly acted, it's just unnecessarily long and covers ground that could probably be covered in 10-15 minutes of a more efficient and interesting movie. 

And then...the movie goes off the rails in a major way. After trudging through the intro, the film hits the gas pedal for what ends up being an equal amount of time of sloppy storytelling, cliche action, and laughable dialogue. With the film's villain not really showing up until the final 20ish minutes one can only wonder at the thought process that led to this final piece of work. Or maybe there wasn't any thought at all. Either way, I want these 90 minutes of my life back.

Absolutely Abysmal.

There are few redeeming qualities in a film like this. Everything from the altered plot line, the characterization, and the lack of any emotional quality, makes this possibly the worst Marvel (and cinematic) entry of 2015.

I for one, am really tired of writers trying to modernize or change classic comic stories, to better suit the audience. They assume that we want something updated, with lots of CGI, and twists and turns along the way. Simpler is always better. The original stories are classic, and beautiful to begin with. The genius struggle of Richard trying to prevent humanity from destroying itself, and from outside threats. The depth of love Susan has for him and the family they build together. Ben's emotional state when he knows there is no going back to his original body, and of course the positvity that the Human Torch carries for the team even in the heat of battle. They were full of struggle and strife, sacrifice and obsession, and a willingness to do good. This movie brings none of those feelings to the screen. The plot is so terribly altered from the original that it makes no effort to connect to it's origin. Everything falls flat.

The actors are so young by comparison to the characters in the comic, that I felt no real empathy towards them. Reed was a genius at birth, but no scene in this film brings about any depth of his intelligence. He's foolish, unintelligent, over-dramatic, and has very little ability to emote (considering Miles Teller's performance in Whiplash). The other characters (2 of which are just CGI monsters) are fairly one dimensional, and lack any real feeling of unity between them as a team. How they managed to do this with one of pop-culture's super families is beyond me.

Truth is, this is what happens when you have poor writing, poor direction, poor editing, poor acting, and a large budget with producers with eyes like dollar signs. Fox ruined this one from the get go.

If you're a fan of the comics (or of movies in general), then avoid this movie like the plague.
