I went into this expecting complete trash due to initial RT ratings. Frankly speaking, it's got a lot of great ideas but has literally the worst editing/pacing I have seen in a long time in a Hollywood budget action film.

I think Marvel's set a precedent of unnecessarily, colorful, nonstop laugh worthy entertainment to the "super hero" genre that now everyone expects and inadvertently wants. Why? Why does everything have to be sandwiched between glib humor and punchlines? Are we really so incapable of being entertained without a laugh? 

Why can't we appreciate a grounded, dark, charmless hard fiction about a bunch of kids who had their lives fucked up?

Ironically what I love about this iteration of Fantastic Four is that the tone of the film is just downright misery. That having cool super powers isn't "fantastic" at all but actually a dreary affair.

That all being said, great ideas don't flourish without the proper execution and F4 just doesn't make a good film. The pacing is all wrong, it's 80% setup, 20% conflict with an abrupt ending. The resolution itself has no build up, none of the characters had time to resonate or interact, cheapening the whole "we're better together" motif. Reed's brilliant master plan to beat Doom was "Make Ben Invisible so he can punch him"? Really? The ending poses a problem too, 4 kids strong arming the US government to give them whatever they want? What? The Franklin kids don't mourn their fathers death, but in fact joke about it when naming the building? What?

F4 felt like a long pilot for a possibly great TV show, one that I would love to watch. Unfortunately it's just not a great film and at the rate people are bashing this movie we're not likely to get any more "episodes".

Absolutely inconsistent, uneven, undeveloped, and completely rushed to its finish without any effort or special effects skill by its studio, this version of Fantastic Four is a horrendous waste of time (for both me and Josh Trank).

We have to use these powers for good!"  I disagree.  If The Human Torch wants to go set the Taliban on fire, let him.  At least that would be entertaining.

While Fantastic Four isn't the worst superhero movie ever made, it will go down as a prime example of confused superhero filmmaking.  There are some interesting ideas in this movie, and somewhere deep down there is a good movie.  The problem however is twofold: studio meddling, and the fact that the movie it's trying to be just isn't a Fantastic Four movie.  The idea of people with powers suffering and being exploited is actually pretty damn intriguing, but it just doesn't fit the tone of who the Fantastic Four are.  They're a family who have grand adventures, and I never felt that with these guys.  They bicker constantly, not like a family, but like people who genuinely hate each other.  They have no adventures really, with the 90% of the movie taking place in one dull location.  If you took away the Fantastic Four brand and went all out with this vision, you could have an intriguing Cronenberg-esque sci-fi trip, something that could go down as a cult hit.  Even with the Fantastic Four name though, if you went all out with this vision you may at least have something kind of interesting, and that's where the second problem comes in: studio meddling.  It's obvious the studio didn't have faith in the director's vision, and while I don't necessarily blame them, their adjustments just make it worse.  They clearly tried to make it a more standard superhero film at the last minute, but the result is just an embarrassingly sloppy climax with cringe-worthy dialogue and ugly CGI.
The biggest shame of this movie is that it could have been good.  Everyone involved from the director to the actors to the studio, they've all produced good products in the past, and they clearly all have a vision for this thing.  The problem is their visions clashed and just didn't fit the property they were working with.  It's not a fun bad movie, it's just a depressingly bad movie.  But hey, at least it's better than Ghost Rider I guess.

New worst Marvel movie I've seen. They changed a ton of things and the cg stuff was pretty awful, especially with the Thing, who looks like some stop-motion photography gone wrong. The plot dealt entirely with them getting their powers, literally the whole movie deals with that bit. Just really, really bad in almost every conceivable way. After seeing the first three attempts at a Fantastic Four movie, going in to its fourth installment, I thought to myself that it couldn't possibly get any worse. Boy, was I wrong. Not only is this the worst Fantastic Four movie, this also might be the worst superhero movie I have ever seen. This film is an absolute embarrassment. With a director like Josh Trank(Chronicle) attached, this film could have been great. There were SEVERAL writers collaborating to make this film. Not one of them stopped and said, "Guys, this movie just isn't working."
Unfortunately, no one did so. THIS WHOLE FILM IS EXPOSITION. The whole movie is a setup for a sequel. Not only that, but the CGI is laughably bad. Fantastic Four had a huge budget, but still managed to create CGI effects in comparison to the original straight-to-DVD film in the 90's. 

    Also, the actors in this film are all considerably talented. But, for some reason, they just couldn't pull it off. Some of the acting in this film is cringe-worthy, especially from Toby Kebbell. Miles Teller is normally great in films like The Spectacular Now or Whiplash. Michael B. Jordan was awesome in Fruitvale Station. Jamie Bell and Kate mara are fantastic actors. Speaking of Jamie Bell, I have no clue what the f**k he was trying to do in this movie. His performance was just not working at all.

   Fantastic Four is a ludicrous film. I would not wish this film on anyone, and I think it's time to stop trying to make Fantastic Four films. I am beginning to think that it is impossible to make a Fantastic Four film. You would be much better off going to see another film such as The Gift.

Simply not nearly as bad as all the criticism has made it out to be. The first 3/5ths are entirely enjoyable. The character arcs were interesting. The problem is one many origin superhero tales have... where to go with it. If this had been a netflix serial a la Daredevil, this would have made a great first couple of episodes. The problem in the cinema format is they need to do more than just introduce you to these characters because we don't get another eight to twenty hours to delve into the issues the movie teases at. That said despite an anti-climatic climax which is even further stunted by painful dialog, the very solid first half of this film gives it more watchable moments than any other 2015 comic book movie.

I'm not sure why this movie was butchered by critics and the casual moviegoer.I enjoyed this film. Why....here is a nice tidy list!
The reboot felt more like a Sci fi adventure than a typical superhero movie
The film was serious, and not corny like the original 
The characters were developed and the plot was not too complicated and not too simple
It was visually pleasing and the director didn't bombard you with a thousand elements of the marvel universe
It was probably one of the best origin stories I've seen recently. 
The film felt like it was a realistic venture, I don't feel that they took shortcuts especially with key elements of the story

Really poor excuse for not only a superhero movie or action movie but a poor excuse for a movie in general. At certain points it's as if the filmmakers were aware the movie was a disaster so they were seeing just how bad they could make it by the end. The time jump ruins the only sign of life the movie showed. Poorly acted across the board which surprised me given the talent level. Fox just doesn't seem to know what they're doing in relation to Marvel's First Family. Anti-climactic, boring, and just plain bad. Fantastic Four (take two) is the least fun blockbuster in recent memory.

The film sometimes dazzles with a visual flare, and there certainly are some interesting concepts at play, but Fantastic Four suffers from a lazy script that fails to define its characters or explain almost anything that happens. For the 100 minutes, you try to enjoy the characters (and the likeable actors portraying them), you try to suspend believe but this mess of a film continues to let its audience down. Instead of becoming the next great superhero franchise, it settles to stay on a similar level as the past Fantastic Four movies people have come to hate (at least those films made some sense, weren't cluttered with half-assed CGI and had some entertaining humor and action). What an unfortunate misfire is all I have left to say.

This movie was profusely disappointing.  At the very least this film was better then the terrible early 2000's Fantastic 4 movies.   But sadly that's not saying much.   While the Tim Story movies were way too goofy this movie was way too dark.   The cinematography, acting and special effects were all great.   But the characters, story and writing all sucked.   The first act of the movie followed the Ultimate Fantastic 4 comics so well.   But then it all started going wrong when they got their powers.   Thing becomes a secret super soldier (how can someone as big as him remain a secret?!?!) and we never get to see any of it. and they try and make them pawns of the government.   Then the the film makes the exact same mistake the previous films made.   Rather then making Dr Doom ruler of Latveria and the inventor of a suit of power armor that could put Iron Man to shame.  They try and give him powers and make him crazy.    Gone is everything cool about the dictator with ambitions of world conquest that is doctor doom.   Thing at least looked great in this movie (although seeing his rocky butt-cheeks was something I could have done without) unlike the thing from the original movie that looked like an action figure sculpted out butterfinger candy bar poop.   Johnny Storm was fun but barely in the movie.   Reed Richards was passable at best and Kate Mara who is a great actress is the invisible woman.  they never use her even close to her whole potential though.   Im convinced that at one time this was going to be a good movie but when Disney/Marvel heard that a franchise that technically belonged to them was going to make money they couldn't get at they secretly went about sabotaging it either out of spite or to protect their holdings.   skip this one stick to the comics.

And when that something finally came, it was more like a "Oh, this is the movie climax?" moment. Dull and lengthy with a good set of actors but a bad script and overall boring storyline.

The end result of the film jumbled mess. At points it's an arthouse indie, at others it's the next Fast and Furious flick, and sometimes it's a Cronenberg body horror! The cast are all solid but the movie just drags. The movie ends up as a 90 minute build up to a 10 minute climax that is boring and filled with sub-par CGI. Fantastic 4, sadly, is not so fantastic.

I literally have no idea what really to say about this movie. First of all, the only job for the filmmakers was to make this movie better than the previous instalments, which shouldn't have been difficult. I mean, Trank maybe had a better ideo to end the movie, but in the end we dont know who to blame, and we have to judge the end result; which is really bad. I guess they were overthinking this one, or maybe not, maye they did just what they came up with and translated it into something called Fantastic Four. The actors did a good job (which I really didn't expect them to do), but there was not a slight bit of chemistry, which the revious movies did a way better job. Focusing more on the struggle of the Thing is also something previous movies tried, and didn't work out. Trying to make Van Doom more than just a man with a mask and gadgets is cool, I liked it, but you can't call that persona Van Doom (just call him metal gear man with head exploding powers ore something). What really hurts in this movie are the painfully obvious reshoots. The worst part is, they dont even make this movie better, they just unnecessarily steal playtime. The climax of the movie took like 17 minutes. Seriously? C'mon, if you struggle to show the audience everything you want, then make this a 2 1/2h movie (even though I highly doubt that would have helped this movie). I think they could make it better (and by THEY I do mean FOX), but I dont really know how to get people to pay for a Fantastic Four movie anymore, and I think this franchise is buried for the next 10 to 15 years. I hope the F4 come back, and we can do them justice (sometime). I will give this movie a better ranking than some other 'better' movies (like Iron Man 4) because the movie at least didn't make me mad. It was disappointing, and it was boring, but it didn't make me jump on a bandwagon and hate on it everywhere I go (LIKE IRON MAN 3, fuck that movie).

Time waste.  So another origins story for the troupe, this is an updated story of how the Fantastic Four came to be.  They travel to an alternate universe and become mutated by the elements of this new planet.  I really don't know why this specific group of superheroes is so hard to get right; so far to date, the only time where it has truly excelled is when it was a different title: The Incredibles.  I can't say that I've seen the Roger Corman production, and I don't have a personal connection with the comic books, but I've seen both of the Tim Story movies, and they ranged from okay to mediocre.  I think those two movies catch an unfair amount of flack, but they're still not good films.  With this reboot, they have made something that is far more lacking than either one of the previous movies.  The best thing I can say about the 2005 movie is that it shows that not every superhero movie had to be brooding and dark, and you can have one be more lighthearted; from my understanding this isn't the darkest of superhero stories anyways.  With this reboot, it is back to basics, and there are dark elements all over the place.  Honestly, this really makes me feel bad for critiquing something like Ant-Man for not being perfect, because with this, there really is nothing to recommend about this, and I will happily watch the entirety of the Marvel Cinematic Universe before I will ever pick this up again.  So where to begin with everything that is wrong with this.  For one thing, there are no surprises to be had here.  It's another origins story for a group that everybody is already well aware of; nobody wants to see another Spider-Man origins, Superman origins or Batman origins, and nobody wants to see this, either.  It's just like a bad cover song at karaoke of a song that wasn't all that great to begin with, and you just want the drunken man to get off the stage.  I am not exaggerating when I say that it takes a full 45 minutes before something new happens.  I have heard differing stories on how much this was studio intervention and how much was director Josh Trank, and it doesn't really matter, because everybody is to blame and we all lose.  These aren't terrible actors; I've seen Miles Teller knock it out of the park in Whiplash, Michael B. Jordan bring it in Fruitvale Station, and Toby Kebbell deliver a gut punch in Dead Man's Shoes.  That said, I feel that every single person here is miscast, and nobody shares any chemistry with one another, they are just going through the motions and reading the lines on the page.  The dialogue is as clunky and boring as the rock planet that they go to, which brings me to the next point: the effects look cheap.  I don't know if somebody pocketed the majority of the $120 million budget, but the special effects look like they could have been rendered another few times over, and to have not one but two of your most climactic scenes take place on a barren rock planet is not an exciting choice to make for your adventure movie.  The villain motivation is weak and questionable, and the more I think about this, the less I like it, and I don't have anything good to say about this overly dull action film, which, in itself, is saying something.

Fantastic Four is thuddingly awful, completely unfun, stupid, and not even bad enough to be funny -- it's a painful eyesore that looks like it was made with the budget of an indie film by idiots who don't know how to use green-screen effectively.

Fantastic Four is the new attempt to making a good Fantastic Four movie.Needless to say it is another very much failed attempt to do so.
Now this movie actually started fine.Reed seemed interesting enough and Miles Teller is actually a very good actor and he was delivering it.Some things don't work even in the beginning of course,but overall it was fine and nothing too terrible about it.
Then the movie tries to be smart and dark which just turns out as laughable and boring.This movie takes itself way to seriously and it really should not have.Unfortunately even the Special Effects very really bad,and I was watching it and asking myself how could a 2015 Superhero movie look so bad.Nothing looked real or believable here.Especially Doom,whose design was really bad and his face looked like so terrible that at a point it just makes you laugh at it.
The overall acting is fine,there's nothing too terrible about it.The dialogue wasn't as terrible either,not most of the time at least because there are some lines that are really bad too.Also the running time is not long at all,but by the end the movie just feels like it's dragging on and that is not a good thing at all.

Josh Trank's "Fantastic Four" is the latest attempt to earn 20th Century Fox some super hero cred outside of the X-Men franchise, but once again, all hopes were dashed come opening weekend. No one knows what caused this disaster of a film, but a great cast of talented actors couldn't get it right, nor a director with enough creativity to build his own superhero movie (in the form of "Chronicle," which was far better than this) was enough to make this franchise into a success. It was dark, gloomy, ultra-scientific with none of the fun and excitement that makes the MCU films SO successful. In short, let's hope Fox cuts their losses and decide not to attempt a sequel- really, who wants it?

We all know the story: Mr Fantastic, The Invisible Woman, The Human Torch and The Thing take on Victor Von Doom, a villain once their own, and infected with the same energy source they have all been affected by, wants to eradicate Earth and only the four can stop him. And in 2015, the Fantastic Four have contracted another chance on the big screen, but this version is a very different interpretation of Marvelâ??s main superhero family to the Tim Story versions of a decade ago. There has been much hype about this reboot that looked intriguing when the trailer came out, but as it has now been released, it seemingly should have followed the recipe for superhero films Marvel Studios have perfected. Unfortunately, this new Fantastic Four capitulates under the numerous mistakes it conceives, much to our surprise, for it has all the elements to be fantastic.
 
Seeing as this version starts off with all the characters separately, they have to bond lots to become tightknit, and unfortunately they never really feel like a group once. We canâ??t ever understand their close bond as friends, siblings, lovers or enemies because we donâ??t get to see them bond, and this is a major problem because to us the characters donâ??t mesh as a unit, and so we see an empty group of heroes who still seem by the end strangers. The characters are thoroughly underused, for only when they talk scientifically do we feel like the film is getting somewhere, but when they try to make small talk for the purpose of character building and relationship bonding, they fail miserably because this script does not make time for it, in fact it fails to make time for any of the moments that make the recent crop of superhero films as successful as they are. Each character cannot be distinguished from one another until their powers ever so poorly cling onto them. They are all brainy scientists with poor upbringings, yet their ambition to do great makes them unique people who struggle to get along with other humans, therefore, all five characters are effectively carbon copies of each other, minus the radical beliefs. So, how can we embrace the characters if the only diversity comes with the usurping of their powers? And to make matters worse, the powers arenâ??t made to look entertaining at all, and like all its problems, we donâ??t see much of it, and when we do, the bits chosen donâ??t tickle our fancy.
 
Miles Teller is our protagonist Reed Richards AKA Mr Fantastic, a genius with the ability to stretch like rubber. Teller falls into his character better than Ioan Gruffudd ever did, but the thinness of his character means shallowness to a lot of things because he is our protagonist. Kate Maraâ??s Susan Storm is far worse than Jessica Albaâ??s creation; all we feel is her cold exterior we can never penetrate. We canâ??t even begin to hope for a romance between her and Richards because her lacklustre performance prevents the idea from even popping into our heads. Michael B. Jordan, despite being black is the sister of Susan, who is white, making her his adopted sister, and to be honest to confuse their lineage doesnâ??t add complexity to anything, it merely makes them feel more like strangers. Because his father is the groupâ??s guide, Jordanâ??s Johnny Storm has depth to his character, unlike his partners, but he isnâ??t even the second or third protagonist! Ben Grimm is the most neglected of the lot, lacking brains and brawn, and screen time! We donâ??t even get to see Jamie Bell that much, but all of a sudden after a mishap is made out of rock, and becomes the heart of the group. This confusion isnâ??t helped by The Thingâ??s poor appearance that blocks emotion. And Victor Von Doom, the villain with a hell-bent vision that Earth needs to be destroyed because humans have driven it to deterioration is a weak enemy. Every feeling of his is under-emphasised, from his hatred of other humans, humanityâ??s treatment of Earth and his love for Susan; therefore he becomes quite a one-dimensional character with the inability to express his emotions. Toby Kebbell does what he can with Victor, but in the end what we have is an undercooked villain with radical beliefs that have come out of nowhere due to his embittered personality that has dealt with constant rejection.
 
The development of the story is interesting at the start, playing upon the inter-dimensional travel ploy that is a big feature for the film, and one we can potentially understand in our technology-heavy society. When teleportation is achieved, the planet they teleport to, named Zero, is the most interesting this film can hope for. It is fascinating that the protagonists go there and actually investigate their surroundings, something which the 2005 Fantastic Four embarrassingly attempts to do, and even though the most we know about this planet is its man-made name and green lava-like substance, there isnâ??t much to remember about it, and that is Fantastic Fourâ??s major problem. It suffers from the inability to delve into the interesting details of its story, which although there are plenty, it doesnâ??t realise which ones are which and suffers. To see a film unable to control its own story, and provide life into memorable superheroes is sad viewing, because Fantastic Four is a mess that has potential, but the filmmakers here havenâ??t understood what constitutes into making a story develop and flow.
 
Fantastic Four cannot flow properly therefore the narrative is unbalanced throughout. The opening is given plenty of time to develop, but the shortness of the running time makes the film miss large sections, which feels like it jumps ahead from scene to scene, and the scenes that are chosen lack importance or clarity. Upon the return of Victor 80 minutes in, the film is suddenly at a climax, allowing the audience to turn to one another and give a stare of â??did I fall asleep or is that it?â?? because the bridging scenes are absent, making this film feel rushed because it fails to dedicate its time equally around the film. About half-way in, the induction of a montage that tries to forward the story in terms of character bonding and the building of the teleportation device shows just how clearly the filmmakers didnâ??t know what they were doing. If the montage were converted into actual scenes, all of the criticism Iâ??ve levelled at the film would be deemed obsolete, because Fantastic Four would then become layered, both in terms of the characters and story.
 
For some reason, the film maintains an obscure tone that suits the film on occasions but cannot be understood why it is so dark. To allow for the characters to bond and for us to create a connection to the film, there has to be far more of a lighter quality to the proceedings, maybe not as much as Chris Evans brought as The Human Torch, but definitely some kind of comic relief that could take the seriousness down a notch or two. I actually donâ??t understand why there needs to be a dark tone because the characters are all young, ambitious and on the verge of ground-breaking discovery, and not once is there the threat of evil until the last 10 minutes, so as you can see the imbalance is rife. Reg E. Catheyâ??s addition as Dr Franklin Storm, parent of Johnny and Sue, whom you may know as the guy who makes tasty-ass ribs in House of Cards, is the guy that brings this gloomy faÃ§ade over the film, despite being a strong character who you can actually feel is acting. His addition gives the characters an anchor they can rebel against and return to, but most importantly his level-headedness stops the characters from relaxing before and after they gain their abilities. Without Franklin as a guide to the group, the gloominess would not have potentially been achieved, and the characters would have had to guide themselves, making for a more reckless film with the capacity to amaze.
 
The short running time means the ending is so lacklustre and insanely quick, it will definitely leave you underwhelmed by the whole experience that didnâ??t develop, intrigue or satisfy such an interesting beginning. The location of the climax is boring, the fighting is tedious and the visuals are so monotonous it would not even take a film buff to notice it. Director Josh Trank has said the final package wasnâ??t his version because 20th Century Fox made cuts to the script without his supervision, and so with his dissatisfaction sky-high, it doesnâ??t change a thing because Fantastic Four was a mess nonetheless. These superheroes need to be left in their comic books fighting evil without critics embarrassing them for a fourth time!
 
The Verdict:
 
Fantastic Four has glimmers of the great superhero film it could have become, but in the end, this reboot has torn apart the charactersâ?? dignity and the worldâ??s love for this family of heroes.
 
â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??        2/10

I went into the cinema ready to make up my own mind. I was so disappointed when I heard that the film was a let-down. Well, it completely bombed basically. I loved the trailer. I was enthralled unbeknownst to me that the film advertised was in fact a FF reboot.

And that's what still sells it to me now despite all the flack it's getting. This is a reboot. It's a stand-alone film with inspiration from famous comics and the characters within them. I guess it's easy for me to say as I don't have any attachment to the comics or their beloved characters.

I adore the fresh, grounded approach to known stories, in this case the younger characters are more modern and seem to deal with 21st century issues. The superpowers are explained by science much like other superhero films but in a way that seems like it could quite possibly happen in the news today. It sounds silly to say that it doesn't feel far-fetched by the atmosphere that engaged me leading me into a reality that made it seem possible.

Using a body horror angle to introduce the characters' powers was a breath of fresh, cool air. To show these characters as real people would behave was something new that I felt needed to be done to refresh the superhero genre. Some effects seemed a little gimmicky but only after a friend pointed it out to me. I think they could've actually taken the whole story in this direction (as the horror was only hinted at and quickly brushed aside) however they chose to skip ahead and get to the action.

Not a lot of people enjoyed the pace of the film, they complained about the lack of action and the slow-burning build that seemed to drag. I however, loved the detail that went into the set-up for these characters as I'm not easily engaged by constant action. And as a reboot, it seemed important and such a good opportunity to flesh out a completely new origin. I think people wanted to see more of the superheroes and didn't care much for the people behind them. Despite this, the characters personalities' were quite one-dimensional which explains why the first 2 acts fell short for a lot of people.

This leads to an issue with the third act, which for the length of the film, seems like an after-thought. In my mind, they could've gone two ways. First, they could've given more running time to allow for a better built-up, fleshed out and authentic action sequence that threaded better into the story rather than choosing a dark and brooding character to suddenly just go, 'you know what? Fuck Earth.' Or, they should've made the final act about what their new bodies would mean for their place in society i.e. make the antagonist the military/government that tries to take their freedom (crudely described; apologies). THEN we could introduce Doctor Doom in the sequel. Get where I'm going?

But alas, this was not the case and therefore this was far from a perfect film. However, I still enjoyed it as a whole based on the sum of it's good parts.
The film is not bad in itself, but there are so many shortcuts in the story it's basically a 100 minutes trailer for a fantastic four movie

F4 starts off really well. First half of the film is scripted intelligently and well paced. It was actually intriguing and had me thoroughly engaged. The 1st half of the film truly felt complete. It's the other half that was a total mess and where it all falls apart. That was also the major problem the film can be dissected by its two acts and quite apparent missing a middle act. Rumors of studio meddling points to this disjointed mess of movie that  could have been otherwise a good picture. Cutting the budget, taking away three major action sequences and took over final cut of the film. Josh Trank is a talented director anyone who has seen Chronicle would know this to be true. I wish he would have been allowed t o make the movie he wanted. I guess we will never see it and for now we have to live with the film that exists now.

This film was very poor from the beginning. It was trying so hard to get the younger crowd more interested in seeing the film by hiring young and popular actors. The plot had holes as well, I mean it just pulled in a nerdy kid who has little experience working in a professional filed, to build  giant teleprter. Then they pretend they need him after he finishes the job, succeeds in getting to the new planet, and then leaves his friends to escape the governments control. All his research was probably closely documented, not to mention his 3 partners who helped in the teleporter's success and are there to help build it! Then the actors were so young that I really hated the affliction given when delivering lines. Like the world is about to end, everyone you love is going to die, and your partner Victor is the cause; and you're telling me your going to SPEAK NOT YELL "Victor don't." Really? I don't feel like you could even act calm in that type of situation. Then the line "I'm a adult, dad!"  This line was delivered very oddly.I would expect either a low and cool delivery or a very loud angry, almost teen way, of delivery. Instead the delivery was a combination of both like the actor could not make up his mind on how to deliver the line. Both the characters Ben and Johnny felt very neglected in the movie as well. The enemy was too over powered and could not have been beat. The fantastic 4 suddenly stop breathing oxygen for the boss fight. Not enough energy after the death of Johnny and  Sue's dad's death. I mean he helped all but Ben through the movie and I feel like a lot of anger and energy would have been released at such a time.  (Johnny did at least show a bit of anger seconds after his father was struck). Reed was just awful. Never really liked the character any way, but with the poor delivery of lines and the character being portrayed in a very fake and, at times, as the actor himself way I just could not believe that reeve was a three dimensional person like we all are. I mean where was the inner thoughts and depth. Sue did have depth but she also got neglected in some parts and just could not carry the other actors with her.The older actors in this move were well seasoned and just very unfortunate enough to be in this film. At times I felt that the actors forced the young actors to actually feel and be in the scenes.The ending sucked not only because of the plot holes and overpowered villain, but because the young actors had to actually carry a scene out by themselves. I admit that being on set with a green screen, no props, and looking up at a, probably, really nice coworker while tying to be in character is hard, but its your job! Like you get paid to act, so do it right! Use your imagination and touch on feelings. Don't be afraid to show your emotions. There was just too much "trying to be cool" going on. The fact that your still young in the movie means you should be showing even more emotion. You haven't had the years to learn how to completely control your emotions and keep cool. In fact I don't think a single person could be in such control at the end of the world. Where is the director! You couldn't tell the actors this?!? Did you not care that they totally forgot how to act? Did you even try to re-film the acting? The only thing that got this in theaters was the fact it marvel, has action, and the graphics were professional. Besides that it sucked.
Even though the third act was tainted by studio executives who don't know jack squat, overall, I actually kinda liked this movie. It's not as bad as the Tomatometer would have you believe.

I am aware of what happened behind the scenes. I'm even aware of how Trank bailed at the last moment and I am definitely aware that the last 20 minutes of the movie needed more work. But you'd be foolish to disagree that this movie had all the makings of a Marvel Studios Movie (The Thor Kind, not the other movies which have levity involved where all the science is just simply deemed as "Alien" to soothe everyone) and that they hired the right talent for it which could've seriously taken it all the way.

OK, so is it a darker movie with awkward jokes and convenient science, rather than a self aware movie, like Guardians of the Galaxy, which gets to joke around about standing in circles? Sure. But its a good movie. Bear in mind, I'm not implying that its the best that Fox Studios has to offer but its still better than all the crap I have suffered through this year that made more money. I understand how you'd think that this thought has no basis of merit but I disagree. Hear me out. Lets assume you enjoyed a movie that everyone else hated on but you kept your silence as you are aware that every movie is subjective, but then suddenly, using the mass consensus as a weapon, everyone dog piles on a movie that you didn't really mind, and you end up getting a bit underwhelmed with the overall response as you liked a movie that everyone else didn't enjoy. And It all just seems like an immature joke that you had a great time with but the others around you didn't really understand or may be even unimpressed by it, which leaves you poking everyone with your elbow saying "huh, huh?"

Well I'm stuck in that category. I am one of those 3 guys that liked that bomb of a bollywood movie called Gunday and faced a similar heat when everyone criticized it based on what they heard rather than what the movie made you experience (despite the flaws), and I'd like to keep F4 on the same platform - As an underrated and severely hated on movie that hopefully, in the future, be considered as, at best, an average movie that we are strong armed to concede with as an "OK movie that history remembered, when it could've easily be forgotten"

P.S.  I think they set themselves up for a sequel and I'd pay my money to watch it.

The plot was non-existent since you had to wait 90 minutes to get to what the plot should have been: Dr. Doom vs. Fantastic Four and it only lasted 5 minutes. Then add in the awful casting. Fantastic Four is a very dark movie. I mean, really dark. I mean dark, as in, somebody please flip some lights on. That's not a joke; every scene in this movie is so under-lit that you feel like your wearing sunglasses indoors. Every outdoor scene feel you're attending a vampire funeral. It is a funerary tone is unfortunately appropriate because this is a joyless, dead serious movie that rings all of the energy out of something that should be bouncy and fun.

This is the fourth failed movie rendition of this property and the fourth time that Hollywood has shown that it doesn't have a clue how to do it right. Roger Corman's legendary 1994 action-comedy was so infamous that it never got released. The 2005 Fantastic Four movie and its sequel Rise of the Silver Surfer, were colorful but featherbrained and forgettable. Yet, they were modern masterpieces compared to director Josh Trank's current modernization, a movie so joyless that makes the last hour of Revenge of the Sith feel like Christmas morning.

At the beginning of the new Fantastic Four - or as the poster calls it, 'Fant-4-stic' - we meet 10 year-old Reed Richards (Owen Judge) who is working on a matter transfer machine.  He becomes friends with young Ben Grimm (Evan Hannemann) whose family owns a junkyard and has the parts that Reed needs. They become friends and grow up working together on the project, but years later at their high school science fair, their teacher (Dan Castelanetta) dismisses their amazing discovery as "a magic show."

The government is more interested in their discovery and gives them access to work on it - along with Sue Storm (Kate Mara) and Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), and a broody drop-out named Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell) who is said to be from Latvaria, but has an accent that is true-blue America. The team is given access to The Least Secure Government Research Facility on the Face of the Earth. Seriously, they can go anywhere, do anything, and send out photos of themselves to their buddies without any restrictions what-so-ever.

The first test of the matter-transfer machine with a chimp is successful, but Reed (played as an adult by Miles Teller) thinks that he and his team would be perfect for the first human test. The project overseer (Tim Blake Nelson) wants to bring in astronauts, but Reed is undaunted and wants to try it out himself. After hours, he gathers the team for an unauthorized test, but things go wrong and they, of course, find themselves with magical powers. Reed can stretch. Johnny becomes a human torch. Ben turns into a walking, talking chunk of rocks. And, for no reason at all, Sue gets the power to turn invisible, which is a head-scratcher because she didn't go on the mission at all - she was at the lab computer, so okay.

The introduction of these elements make up the movie's first hour. We are laboriously introduced to every single character. Then after the accident, we are laboriously introduced to all of their superpowers. By the time the introductions are over, we have time for a ten minute action scene before the movie abruptly ends. The worse section of the movie are the discovery of the powers. What should be a moment of joy and discovery is a long, sad series of 'what-have-you-done-to-me' scenes that have the same tone as if someone's dog just died.

The idea here should yield a movie that is as joyful and fun as last year's Guardians of the Galaxy. Quite the opposite. This is a grim, mean-spirited and broody movie. Instead of a fantasy, we get the approximation of how these events might play out in real life. That's exactly the wrong approach. The characters spend much of the time getting to know each other that you feel like you're watching the pilot to a TV series.

The comic books, as I remember them, were colorful and fun. The team felt like a cohesive family unit whose chief quirk is that their differing personalities meant that they were always playfully squabbling with one another - like a family. Here they seem to have been pulled together from central casting. The actors do what they can, but never at any time are they required to give us any sense of joy or wonderment. What was the thinking here? Why make a summer action movie this gloomy and oppressive? Why spend 90% of the movie on introductions? Why set the entire movie in a lab? Why give it such a mean-spirited tone? Fans of the movie won't recognize the characters.  Non-fans will be repelled by the movie's repellant atmosphere.  Who was this movie made for?

NOTE: There are no credit cookies, midway or at the end.  Which is okay, because the less time spent with this mess, the better.

In an era where superhero movies are the biggest box office attractions and dominate the summer movie season, its alarming to find a movie so dull, boring, and soul-less as Fantastic 4, or as 20th Century Fox has decided to spell it for some reason, Fant4stic. The movies first and second acts are relatively unoffensive. While not exactly exciting or even fun to watch, it would have been just average enough to make this movie OK. I started to get worried when, 45 minutes into the movie, it seemed that nothing relevant  had happened in the plot yet. The heroes still hadn't gotten their powers, there had been no big action set-pieces we come to expect at this point, and none of the characters had developed in a way to make me feel any emotional connection towards them. Then the film begins to fall apart at a baffling pace, as the words "ONE YEAR LATER" appear on the screen right in the middle of the second act. What follows is a few poorly edited, short and boring action sequences that look like they were ripped directly out of a sci-fi channel original movie. Then the bad guy shows up and decides to destroy the world for absolutely no reason at all, the boring heroes fight him in one of the worst third acts I've ever seen in a movie, and then it just ends with some of the most painful to listen to dialogue I've ever heard in a movie my entire life. If you like superhero movies, or even movies in general, don't watch this film for any reason.

I was looking forward to this when I first saw the trailer.  Then I heard about the problems during production and issues with the director. Then the reviews came out. I decided that I would go ahead and see it on the big screen.  
First, it doesn't help that Marvel wasn't in charge.  It's not as good a film as what's been produced for the MCU but that's ok.  Marvel has done a wonderful job and set the bar high.  I'm sure that hurt the reaction here some. I enjoyed the story. It was good enough for a reboot. I thought the acting was fine. SFX was good as well. I liked how the relationship between Reed & Ben was fleshed out.  It did seem that 3/4 of the film was devoted to the origin.  That seems like a lot more than the other superhero films that deal with origins.  I suspect that hurt reviews too. After the 4 find themselves capable of using their powers, it seems like the film has less superhero action than other films and the climatic battle is rather straight forward and relatively short. I'd watch another film with these characters. I hope I get too but I understand I'm definitely in the minority in my view of this one.

The special effect are pretty good and the acting is as good as any other movie in this genre. And it's fun to see familiar actors from a bunch of other recent movies. Gritty and more grim (see the Thing I did there? ;) ) than its predecessor, and with a younger cast that doesn't quite have the experienced acting chops and put the movie into a Teen TItans kind of realm. Also has a couple of annoying sexist jabs - Sue being essentially the costume maker (engineering of space suits aside) and the "pattern recogniser" were a little grating. However, POC representation is up which is a bonus. Also at times hyperviolent.

After the overall O.K. previous Fan 4 films, all Trank and the team at 20th Century Fox needed to do was to make a worthwhile film, about a team of friends who had to adjust to life with their new-found Superpowers.

That was the one thing Fox absolutely couldn't do. 

The First mistake in this film is the director. Yes, Trank was a good choice at first, but the more reports came in of Trank's behaviour on set, and after Kate Mara (Susan Storm/The Invisible Woman) was told not to read the comics, and Trank was allegedly turning up to set drunk, and shutting himself off from society, the movie was immediatley doomed.

The Second thing they screwed up with the film was the characters. None of these characters projected the original wit and fun of the comic book heroes. Even though the actors (Mostly Teller as Reed Richards, Mara as Sue Storm, Bell as Ben Grimm and B. Jordan as Johnny Storm though) tried to save the film, no-one could really help the fact that the script was witless, and the characters were pointless. The main disappointment in this aspect of the film however is the plain lazyness and downright insulting way the villian - Viktor Von Doom/Doctor Doom was written. Instead of being an evil egomaniac bent on revenge towards his former friends, he becomes a stupid, video game playing nerd, who has a slight crush on Sue, and is angry cause he got... um... burnt a bit? 

The Last and most important part of this film that they screwed up, was the pacing. I timed the film, and 45 minutes into the film, and it's an hour and a half long film, 45 minutes in, they return from Planet Zero, with their powers. Then the credits are about 7 minutes long, so you minus 7 from around 45 minutes, brings you to around 38 minutes. They have their powers in this film for 38 minutes, minus the time it takes them to do the most expositioney piece of writing of all time to explain their power which is about 5 minutes, so that brings us to 33 minutes of them having their powers. And to make matters worse Doctor Doom returns as the villian for the final fight, 15 minutes before the film ends. And 5 of those minutes, is the final fight, Doctor Doom is expositioned for 10 minutes, and in those minutes: He kills about 30 people by exploding their heads, with... his mind? I guess. Reed and Ben talk. Johnny accidentally attacks Sue. Doctor Doom kills Sue and Johnny's father. The World starts to get sucked up into a black hole. 
Hang on while we're on the subject of the final fight and that god damn wormhole piece of crap, lets focus souley on that. So Doctor Doom was trapped on Planet Zero for a year now, and somehow found a hoodie cloak (no seriously where'd he get that?) and when he comes back, hes already figured out how to blow up people's heads or suck the life out of them or something, and create a freaking Black Hole? Yeah sure, it looked cool. But it was a piece of shit. I mean come on, Doom created a freaking Black Hole with his mind, and then, um, what was his plan after that? What was he supposed to try and do? What was his goal in life? WHY DID DOCTOR DOOM EXIST!!!

If this was a film about a group of kids getting superpowers, and trying to learn how to deal with them, and then one (Viktor) goes rogue and they team up to stop him. It would've been great, it may have even been one of the best superhero films of all time. It had potential, but FANT4STIC is a clear defintion that Superhero films can still suck balls

Once excited about the notion of a new big-budget Fantastic Four movie that featured the presence of Miles Teller and Michael B. Jordan, I ended up watching it when I heard neverending critical scorn and so I had to learn precisely what rendered it to terrible.
 
Faster than Johnny Storm can fly, audiences will realize that The Fantastic Four is anything but fantastic. Before the story can actively allow audiences to get a sense of the situation, it already hurls its characters into an overdriven pace. A good superhero movie knows how to pace itself appropriately. If it is going to be commercial and blockbuster-oriented, then it needs to be fast and action packed. If it is intending to be a really atmospheric piece, it has to sensibly moderate character building with spectacle. With Fantastic Four, there is no sensibility in the pacing.  
The fact that the story gives no time before it throws viewers into a point in Reed Richards' life where he is a child who speaks of exceeding interest in scientific discovery before being shot down by his teacher is not just cliche, but it makes no sense whatsoever. To characterize him as a child prodigy is one thing, but to turn him into a paper-thin cartoon character building a teleporter in his garage after failing to "build a flying car" is a new level of juvenile. The film has not even given audiences two minutes before it is already doing this. One of the first lines in the film is "When I grow up, I want to be the first person in human history to teleport himself". That should tell you how instantly the film just throws plot dynamics at viewers. And the decision to make the line "It's clobberin' time!" a line used by Ben Grimm's older brother upon attacking him is just a massive slap in the face for fans of the comic book series and people with any sense of intellect anywhere in the world watching this film. 
Before the film reaches ten minutes, Reed Richards and Ben Grimm have created an advanced teleporter as teenagers, been disqualified from the Science Fair by the voice of Homer Simpson and then given a scholarship. It all goes by in a senseless rush, and yet this is misleading because straight after than the pace takes a sudden drop. From there, there is more than half an hour of characters just building a teleporter and discussing unappealing scientific jargon and tedious character subplots which have a real lack of practical drama. The characters don't actually gain their powers until halfway through, and by that point many viewers will have stopped caring anyway. Alas, I decided that despite my pessimism I would soldier on.
After they get their powers, there is suddenly a massive ellipsis which jumps significantly ahead in time, and we see the characters have learned to use their powers through very brief clips of footage. The story points out that they are being utilized as tools of the military, and this brief segment shows impressive visual effects to boot. For a $120 million film I would expect nothing but the finest visual effects, and the film does boast some top notch CGI, particularly in the design of The Thing whose detailed stone shell, stature and movements are all very effective. The Thing gains special props for being so much more convincing than the cheesy prosthetic worn by Michael Chiklis in the Tim Story films. And yet, the quality of the visual effects just makes the experience of the film so much more disappointing when Josh Trank can't find anything to do with them. Despite the production values of the film, the $120 million production that is Fantastic Four would rather rush through a story plagued by too much talking and too little action. The action scenes are the best moments in the film because the combat the characters engage in proves entertaining, but there is never slightly close to enough of it. The film reverts back to talking very fast, and even though the titular team are now working with the military, they are put to no use. After an extremely brief moment where audiences see that Mr. Fantastic can be put to use with an effective use of his powers in the action, the film reverts back to its meandering path of tedious character conflict. The action is kind of thing audiences are going to actually want to see, and the fact that nobody bothers to acknowledge that really weighs down on the experience even further. The best scene in the film is its final action climax, though this has nothing to do with the narrative. The action climax is extremely brief, bereft of any genuine feeling and just an example of wasted funds values on a film which could have donated its funds to far superior material trying to enter production as we speak. And in the blink of an eye, it's over, as is the entire film. The feeling I was left with was worse than when I experienced Gavin Hood's adaptation of Ender's Game. Ender's Game used a misleading narrative to leave the viewer feeling like they were waiting for an action climax only to be told they had already experienced it. That pissed me off. And yet, Fantastic Four offered a different way to achieve the same result. The film is a mere 100 minutes long and spends the time dashing through many plot points while dragging on for others, rendering the already-thin narrative one which just collapses in on itself. And as a result, the story goes nowhere. So when the film reaches its sudden climax, it feels like the story is simply at a midpoint where it is suddenly turning everything around with a conventional burst of action. In actual fact, this is the end point in the movie, meaning that Fantastic Four ends just before the point in time that most films would call their halfway point. It's incomprehensible to the point that it's hard to describe, but it's the kind of feeling I've never really had before. It's one I never wanted to have, so I would advise you not to watch the film to experience it.
Frankly, what's ridiculous is just how Fantastic Four manages to be both similar and different to the 2005 rendition and still mess up both parts. The lack of action is the same mistake made by Tim Story with his first Fantastic For movie, and I just don't get how a film with a $120 million budget ends up so lifeless and short on action. I mean, where else is there for the money to go? It's certainly not into the screenplay because the writing is pathetic. The saying "talk is cheap" applies here because the dialogue has no dramatic heft to it, nor does it put any interesting characterisation into those being depicted. As it is, the film's intro gives a cheesy characterisation to Reed Richards and Ben Grimm before audiences are left with subpar glimpses into the lives of Sue and Johnny Storm. The former is especially strange as it conflicts with the grim and serious tone of the rest of the film. Unlike the 2005 film, Fantastic Four really takes itself seriously as a legitimate character piece even though it clearly has no idea what the concept of "character" actually is. This doesn't help the cast because they are forced to play figures that are too young to maintain fidelity to the source material. Even though they are clearly talented actors, it is clear that with everything else in the film working against it. There is no saving Fantastic Four or even the cast, but they do prove to take a stand for their own credibility.
Miles Teller delivers a somewhat charismatic performance as Reed Richards. He is instinctively able to capture the appropriate mindset for the character because his tone of voice ensures that the way he delivers the scientific-related dialogue in the film feels really natural to the character. Miles Teller is easily able to convey the intelligent nature of the character, but he also makes a decent impression during the action. What little action he is assigned proves to be something he works with as he picks a convincing punch in the face of either the military or Doctor Doom. He does it during a short period of screen time which is an effective boost for his credibility. And though there is no room for development or genuine emotion in the part, Miles Teller does what he can within such boundaries and delivers a solid effort.
Unfortunately, the same cannot be said about Kate Mara. Condemned to having the most melodramatic character in the story, Kate Mara is doomed from the start because she is constrained by blatant repetition. There is little appeal in her, and her chemistry with Miles Teller has no flair. While Jessica Alba was a terrible Sue Storm, at least she was sexualised to a point where she had some sense of value. With Kate Mara, the writers respect her enough not to condemn her to playing a one-dimensional sex object but not enough to give her a genuine character to work with. Kata Mara's legitimate talents as an actress are not valued enough in Fantastic Four and she has little to offer in terms of gimmicks so she is simply a boring presence.
Michael B. Jordan also delivers a decent effort, though the character he is served with is pathetic. I have little concern with the race of Michael B. Jordan in casting, but it is unfaithfulness to the source material and changes Johnny Storm from being Sue Storm's biological brother. Now, she is his adopted sister and so the relationship changes. There is not even an attempt to characterize any kind of familial bond between them. And at the same time, the sense of comic energy that made Johnny Storm the one good thing about the 2005 Fantastic Four film is diverted into mild elements of African-American stereotyping for the sake of humour. It is too restrained to lay down any effect and too wrong for the character to do anything but cause viewers to question the film even more. But still, what's obvious is that Michael B. Jordan is a strong actor because he makes the attitude of Johnny Storm feel genuine while making a naturally likeable character out of the part. Also, when the visual effects set him ablaze, he really embraces the nature of his superpowers and flies with determination to throw fire in the face of adversity. Michael B. Jordan's natural charisma transcends the blank slate he is thrust upon in his portrayal, and so he has mild appeal despite being far from a true Johnny Storm.
And Jamie Bell follows the same meandering path as he bears little resemblance to either Ben Grimm or especially The Thing. The man is the actor from Billy Elliot playing an overtly masculine figure of stone, failing to capture any sense of brute physical strength in the part. And also, his voice is clearly mismatched for taking on The Thing because it lacks the dank level of booming brute strength to be capable of delivering the iconic line "It's Clobberin' Time" with any sense of actual power behind it. Jamie Bell hides behind visual effects for most of the film, but whether he is on screen or merely voicing a CGI creation, he makes no such impact.
Toby Kebbell also proves to deliver a lifeless and shallow effort.

So though Fantastic Four has some of the right cast and visual effects, they are used exceedingly minimally while playing second fiddle to a pathetically written and incompetently paced excuse for a story.

This 4th attempt at a Fantastic Four film had all the cards on the table to make a truly unique and excellent take on the superhero team, but miraculously managed to create one of the all-time biggest blunders in recent memory; it's truly awful. Josh Trank was on his way to a promising career after his sleeper hit, Chronicle shocked the world, but after many issues on-set, the film undergoing massive re-shoots, and the studio intervening and eventually taking over production, I'm quickly reminded of what happened to David Fincher on Alien3. The cast were all capable and I was very excited about Miles Teller as Reed Richards, but none of them seem to want to be there, they have no chemistry, and there's hardly any scenes with all four of them in it working together. There are some good moments in here like the body-horror angle they took to introduce their powers, the special effects are updated (most notably on The Human Torch), and Doctor Doom's rampage near the end played out more like a slasher film with a level of violence unsuitable for a PG superhero film! That is all I enjoyed however and there are too many problems to list but I will detail the major ones: the script is terrible and was re-written so many times it is an absolute mess, there is almost no action scenes with the climactic battle lasting about five minutes, nearly the entire film takes place in three settings and was pretty much shot on a sound-stage, the movie spends no time showing us how the heroes adapt to their powers and instead makes the critical error of jumping forward a year in advance to where they're already being militarized, and there is laughable continuity issues between the re-shoots with Sue Storm's hair changing style and colour *face-palm*. It is astonishing that a film this bad can still be made in 2015, especially one part of the 100% profitable superhero craze, but the evidence of inexperience, studio meddling, and lack of inspiration is all over this "film" that's only reason for existence was to hold onto the film rights....because that worked SO WELL with The Amazing Spider-Man.

This much, much derided Fantastic Four reboot is so much better than you've heard, for the best part of an hour there is a real attempt  to make a proper sci-fi movie, it plays like a real movie an not some skittles coloured, cartoon smash up. It's gripping and exciting to watch these young scientists attempt to crack interdimentional travel, and then it turns,intriguingly, into a sort of sci-fi horror for a stretch (haha) especially when Dr Doom shows up and starts going all Scanners on everyone in a secret lab, theres some truly rating pushing gore going down in this fairly awesome part of the film. Then it turns to buisness as usual, stop the bad guy/save the world, you know the whole spiel. But this is a refreshing superhero movie and unlike so many misguided post Dask Knight comic book movies this one attempts to not simply make everything more dark and broody than it should be, it dose what these films should now be trying, to make a proper genre movie out of a superhero concept, and it dose it so very well for a long time, sure it falls apart a bit and has some truly terrible effects here and there, but i think this is one of the most interesting films of it's kind in quite a while. Dont listen to all the hate, see for yourself.

20th Century Fox obviously forced director Josh Trank to make major cuts to his film therefor, undermining serious character development and plot advancement. If these cuts & changes weren't forced upon him and despite several amateurish looking shots, I feel Tranks' original vision of this movie would probably be, well, fantastic. There is a masterpiece version of FANTASTIC FOUR here, just under the surface. Despite what you have probably heard this FF movie is NOT the horrible movie it's been made out to be! Neither Fantastic nor Four-star, the latest comic book movie reboot to hit cinema screens sometimes makes for interesting viewing, but ultimately lacks the X-factor or Avengers initiative necessary to make it out-and-out Marvel-ous. Like Batman Begins, this re-do tries anchoring the particulars of the Fantastic Four's origin tale in reality. The problem is: The particulars of this specific comic book title simply prove too fantastical to present as believable. Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight saga involves a rich, psychologically-scarred vigilante with no super powers, but this much different hero property involves a human Stretch Armstrong, a man made of rock, a racer who spontaneously bursts into flame and an invisible woman. No amount of taking a naturalistic approach is going to convince popcorn-munching moviegoers that a computer programmer gets sub-atomic powers from the fourth dimension or that somebody actually names their kid "Victor Von Doom." Worse, an inordinate amount of time gets spent laying this groundwork to make the mechanics behind the titular foursome seem plausible. Unfortunately, this doesn't amount to a great deal of entertainment value in the long run ... and it definitely feels like a long run. For a movie so interested in plausibility, however, the last act reeks of blockbuster schlock. From predictable deaths to shoehorning in superhero catchphrases to the big bad confrontation, it follows some familiar gamma rays down a rote rabbit hole. Worse, it nearly negates the interesting build-up that precedes it. Why flirt with realism at the outset if you're just going to turn cornball near the end? Marvel Studios exhibits a genius knack for straddling the comic-al and true blue spectrums in their projects, tongue always in cheek. Fantastic Four just goes from one extreme to the other in what's more of a flame-out than flame-on. 

In this PG-13-rated adaptation of the classic Marvel comic book, four young scientists (Teller, Mara, Michael B. Jordan, Jamie Bell) achieve superhuman abilities through a teleportation experiment gone haywire and return to a world in need of their new-found abilities. 

Though the director usually goes down with the ship, Josh Trank (who already made a believable, albeit dark, superhero tale with Chronicle) at least takes a interesting approach. He spends ample time with these characters and high falutin' ideas, which makes the third act's descent into cheese seem more like studio tinkering than his own temporary lapse of reason. Moviegoers deserve to see his complete vision, especially considering the spot-on performances that result from his ace casting. Considering the believability factor of the first act, it won't be superb but it will doubtlessly not silver surf into complete oblivion like this fantastic mess.

Bottom line: It's Blubbering Time

The first 25 minutes or so, actually made me somewhat interested in the movie, but it just kept going and going. I constantly kept checking my watch even though the movie is less than 2 hours. The sets are boring only being a concrete military base and a desolate rocky planet, but this can be forgiven if the film had interesting characters, but sadly it does not. The Fantastic Four are suppose to be not only a team but a family as well; they joke with one another, discus things, and work as a team, the don't do any of that in the film, well except maybe for the last part but that was only because they have to. There's not even a brother/sister dynamic in the film and that would've been interesting but they barley even bring it up. Our "heroes" aren't the only one this movie messed up either, they make Doctor Doom such a waste of potential. You finally have the chance to give us, at least, a decant Doom, but his character just feels rush and isn't at all an interesting character, and it's a shame, since Toby Kebbell gave us an incredible movie villain last year as Koba in Dawn of the Planet of the Apes. Doom is also one of the worst looking character I've seen in a superhero film, right up their with bat nipples, and Halle Berry Catwoman. Fantastic Four might be one of the worst superhero films I've ever seen, and it pains me to think that now the 2005 movie will now be known as the good Fantastic Four; Fox should just give up, and hand the rights over to Marvel.

Targeted as the worst Marvel movie of all time - which resulted from a young tyrant director on a coke binge; raging fury on his entire cast and production team.  Fox's decision to re-write his script caused a $10,000 hotel room temper tantrum and created a very poor work environment for everyone involved with the film.  The end result isn't as horrible as everyone says it is, but it still deviates from the expected stellar quality Marvel norm.  It begins very promising, but keeps the viewer locked inside a interesting introduction right up until the last twenty minutes.  Kind of like if SPIDERMAN spent half the movie turning into Spiderman then learned about his powers (off-screen) in containment.  It's not very much fun when the government has control before the superheroes have a chance to play with their abilities on their own.  Instead of it actually being about The Fantastic Four, it's mostly about the pros and cons of creating a portal to another dimension.  One villain is predictably fought at the end of the movie with humdrum spacey special effects.  Actions scenes need to be within public locations and have must normal people being subjected to all the chaos.  Watching characters fight on another planet surrounded by empty space and rocks creates more of a cartoon experience rather than something relatable.  Overall, this one rides the line that separates a great Straight-To-DVD movie from a bad theatrical release.

Oh my goooooooosh! Why is it so hard to make a good Fantastic Four movie?!! WE'VE TRIED FOUR FREAKING TIMES! THEY'VE ALL FAILED! It's also worthy to note that this is the worst attempt yet. This movie is boring, stale, depressing, unfunny, and to sum it up: Awful. This movie probably has the most horrible pacing I have ever seen in a movie ever. The movie spends FIFTY FREAKING MINUTES setting up the characters, then DOESN'T DO ANYTHING WITH THEM AFTER THEY HAVE POWERS. The first half is mildly enjoyable while watching it, but after watching the full movie, it makes you realize how much of your valuable time the first half of this movie wasted. The second half may as well go down as one of the worst acts of a superhero film ever, alongside X-Men Origins: Wolverine's third act and the entirety of Superman IV. The butchering of one of Marvel's best villains cannot go unpunished either, as it is worse than SM3's Venom, Origins Wolverine's Deadpool, and IM3's Mandarin. The finale is as rushed as the film itself, and the last lines of dialogue are literally like the movie is sticking a middle finger in your face. This is one of those movies that you hate while watching, and it gets worse the more you think about it. The acting is boring, the writing is cringe-worthy, the CGI and greenscreen is atrocious, the chemistry is nonexistant, the pacing is unbelievable, the third act is hilariously laughable, and the movie itself is a disgrace to your eyeballs. This movie makes the Tim Story Fantastic Four movies look like Sam Raimi's first two Spider-Man movies and the Dark Knight Trilogy combined in comparison. If you couldn't tell already, DON'T WATCH THIS ATROCITY. 1.5/10

I hate to give any movie one star but this movie was pretty tough to watch. If you don't read comic books you think, hey if they change the origin story that is okay....no it is not. If you haven't guess from watching The Avengers movies, everything that happens is connected to the MCU. If you change the Origin story, you change the Fantastic Four's relationship to that universe. I didn't mind the younger cast or the dynamic of the team, but the traveling to alternate dimensions that gives them their powers...didn't make any sense to me especially since Sue Storm actually didn't travel to the other side but also develops equal amount of change to her body. Dialog was terrible in this movie. Reed & Sue had zero chemistry. It was just a silly attempt at reimagining something that was not broken in the first place. Sadly, by not sticking with the Origin story of the original comics, you also lost the audience who has read hundreds of these comics, alienating fans of Stan Lee & Jack Kirby. Can you imagine a Superman story without Kypton blowing up and without him being found by the Kents or a Batman without his parents dying? Hollywood you should know better...I still can't find anyone who think liked the 1998 Godzilla movie.

The film that fails to live up to its' previous attempts, and that is not saying much. The fourth attempt at a Fantastic Four films tries to add a dark spin on the doomed franchise. Providing the audience with too much set-up and not enough of the team. The four actors try their hardest to give a decent performance while the story crumbles. The villain in the film makes it seem like the writers forgot that a villain was needed in a superhero film and wrote him in at the last second. The plot has a hopeful concept, but it is not able to hold the attention of even the casual viewers. Overall, Fantastic Four is yet another miss in the chain of reboots, but a sequel with the right script could possibly redeem this rendition.

Plain and simple, this movie is a mess. 
It feels like the entire middle section was cut and replaced with a "One Year Later" title card. The heroes go from being horrified by their powers to mastering them in mere seconds of screen time. 
The tone is constantly changing. At first it's science fiction, then it's horror, and finally it's an action film.
Despite a talented cast, the characters are rather uninteresting and have zero chemistry. The central theme of the Fantastic Four comics is family, but the film version of these characters certainly don't feel like one.
The villain (my personal favorite comic book character) is wasted. Though he's set up at the start, he doesn't really become a threat until the very end. He's quickly and neatly disposed of.
In the words of the Human Torch himself, this movie is "the thing nobody wanted." It's a waste of resources, a talented cast, and years of far superior source material. It's just a shame.

An original take on a well known comic book team that falls flat of its potential.  All the critics of this movie, while repetitive and often annoying...were also fairly accurate in their universal feeling of disappointment.  The movie builds and builds, skipping potential character development, jumping to quick snippets of special effects and montages to try and cover for the lack depth.  It then culminates in a less than epic climax that starts and ends within a 15 minute timeframe.  It seems that rather than hearing the initial internet critiques (before the film was finished) and trying to ensure the finished product put everyone in their place...the film, instead, took the fears of the audience to heart and did their best to make a forgettable comic book film that is better suited to act as cannon fodder.  The only ideal scenario now is that its failure to entertain helps push the rights to make F4 movies to Marvel Studios so they might make something that audiences will actually enjoy watching.

Worst movie ever?  Makes the last two films look like gold?  I wouldn't go that far.  This film is nowhere near being GOOD, but it's not nearly as bad as people are making it out to be.  Sure there's a few cringe worthy moments and sequences that leave you scratching your head, but nothing as bad as watching Mr. Fantastic disco dance with two babes in a nightclub set to a top 40 summer track.  
This movie is just THERE.  A giant empty shell of a movie shrouded with special effects.  It's boring, dull, and doesn't have an ounce of luster to it's name.  But is that grounds for calling it 'worse than it's predecessor'?  I mean sure, a movie can be boring from time to time.  But i rather watch a boring movie over a cliche summer blockbuster that makes me laugh at how poorly it's made.
You can blame what you will for this feature.  You can blame a indie director facing the hardships of a big bad studio.  You can blame the studio for wanting too much control.  You can blame the writer and director for not putting forth an effort to make something memorable.  But the truth of the matter is FANTASTIC FOUR IS A SHITTY COMIC BOOK.  It's tacky, it's cheesy, it's downright stupid and I've never liked it.  
You can see that the writer and director KNEW this fact, and tried to change it's structure to make it shine.  But try as they did, it still failed miserably.  
So is this the worst movie of the summer?  I wouldn't stretch it that far, but it certainly is worthy of being in the category.  My rating, 2 out of 5 stars.

First of all the whole Fantastic Four story outside of the movies, the basic Fantastic Four concept is not a popular one. They were not particularly popular in the original comics and not later on. Even with Jessica Alba's appeal in the 2005 version it still was a bad idea, never mind all the problems with those movies. Now they go and do another one? Whose genius idea was this? There are so many great ideas out there, comics and story concepts that have gone unnoticed or yet to be given their due, and they go and try to reboot Fantastic Four??? So what did they create? Well first of all they switch out a main character to a black guy, the sort of thing that offends devotees to a series like this, who are for the most part the only ones wanting to see this. It is political correctness run amok, or in the case of the movie Annie, was actually an anti-white racist attack meant to slight whites by changing a cultural icon-- something that blacks would never allow if the roles were reversed. I run off topic though. To change up a character to appeal to political correctness is ridiculous. People do not like it. Will we see a white Fat Albert in the future? Never. Point made. Moving along the movie is just horrible for all the reasons that so many other CGI monstrosities are horrible. They lack a good story, the acting is poor, and the structure is terrible. I was never interested in any of these characters and certainly was not made to care what happened to them or why. To Hollywood I say this, pick up one of those sensational new comic ideas out there and make it gold instead. People want to see fantastic things, but they want a good story.
