Despite the possibility for greatness that Fantastic 4 has being based on a well established and enjoyable comic from Marvel, the film failed to inspire.  A dull start that seemed to be setting up for the main storyline was dragged out into a film almost entirely composed of exposition that could have been covered in half the time, allowing for some actual action.  While technically being introduced relatively early in the film, the main antagonist wasn't brought to the front of the action until towards the end of the film in what was probably meant to be a plot twist, an assumption based on earlier events of the film, however this would only be surprising to those who fall into the unfortunate category of having neither read the comics, seen the cartoon series, heard of the characters before, didn't pay attention to the character's name, have never seen a film before, or are dense enough to not suspect what was going to happen.  While some parts of the film were exciting these were far and few between, with the final fight scene making up a pitifully small amount of screen time and being rather anticlimactic, leaving a distinct feel of disappointment.  Although a far better adaptation than the prevision films, there is little else of merit;  the pace was slow, the script was mediocre at best, the dialogue was clunky, and the characters were almost as thin as the plot.  It truly is a pity as the main cast showed a lot of potential to make a good film, but were let down by the script and execution.  It felt more like a cheap backstory subplot than a film in it's own right, feeling as though it was simply an attempt to establish a franchise for monetization rather than produce a good film.  The only thing that can be hoped for is that if, after such a disappointing film, the sequel isn't dropped that it will be all action, since this film did all the exposition and backstory that a franchise will ever need.

Don't confuse this for me saying it's a great movie, or anywhere close to what Disney's Marvel movies or the Xmen movies are like. No. Far from it.
The script was EXTREMELY poorly written. The cast - Micheal B Jordon, Kate Mara, Miles Teller, Jamie Bell - If you know Hollywood, you KNOW these are some of the BIGGEST young actor talents that will surely rise to Oscar level one day (Miles' film already did!) and it is disappointing to see how they underperformed here. The relationship between Reed and Ben was developed nicely then abandoned. Sue and Reed lines were so weak there could be no chemistry. And well Johnny just lacked the energy that character is supposed to have. He was mostly angry the whole time. I think Victor Von Doom was the only one who was convincing for me, why he hated people and how he felt about things, which again got completely wasted due to such a pathetic ending for one of the BIGGEST villains in the Marvel universe, with 20th Century fox was SO LUCKY to have since Disney's Marvel cant ever use it till Fox gives rights back... and it got wasted. 
Then those special effects... SO POOR. Was i watching the last Fantastic Four movie? The Thing looked awesome though, yet we never saw enough of our heroes fight enough and see their powers in full action . 

Fantasic Four is one of Marvel's BIGGEST and BEST comic titles in history! It sits up right there next to Spider-man. It was Marvel's answer to Justice League (no, the Avengers weren't). THATS what made me sad. They kind of wasted the property with such weak script, directing and acting. And I dont care if the studio super meddled with Josh Trank's work! He should have just left the film like Edgar Wright did with Ant-Man.

HOWEVER, all this being said, F4 is NOT a horrible movie. Not even remotely. The first hour is very watchable! They have this sci-fi horror theme going on, a completely new take. They build a nice mystery about the unknown universe. Dr. Doom walking through the halls blowing people's head was slick! And Mr. Fantastic's power use was so much more creative than the last movie! The problem is, instead of building up, the film just goes down, and the final act doesn't redeem it, rather makes the most sloppy bit. BUT, I ENJOYED WATCHING THIS FILM. I does NOT feel like a waste of my money! 

So if you like superhero movies or sci-fi films, I would ask you to consider this. Go on a late weekday for lesser cost. But watch it once before you judge it form other's reviews.

Ps.- I am NOT really forgiving about movies (unless it has spider man :P) nor do i give a good rating easily. I know this was a poorly made film. BUT it didnt feel a waste of time n money and i liked it. It is still NOT a "Batman & Robin" or "Green Lantern" bad

I feel really conflicted about this movie. It starts out good with a 1950s sci-fi feel and a great tone to match, even if the pace for this part of the film is slow and the personalities and relationships among the protagonists are nearly nonexistent. Like the crew's interdimensional voyage, everything pretty much goes to heck around that point of the film, with characters acting dumb and a boring third act that comes out of nowhere, clashes with the earlier sections of the movie and is simply dropped into the narrative. Our big bad guy, Dr. Victor won Doom (played by Tony Kebbell) does not have any real reason to be evil or threaten our heroes in the movie except for the fact that the script tells him to do so! The resolution to the plot feels so unearned and is so dumb that you can only laugh at how lame it is. For me, while it is not the jarring disaster or waste of time everyone was predicting, the only worthwhile parts of the movie that save it from being completely missed opportunity are the beginning section of the story and the visual effects bringing the Thing (portrayed by Jaime Bell) to life. It does make you wonder what a better version of this movie might be like, though.

There is actually no second act; no middle. We jump from the origins of their powers to the final conflict. At least the earlier two movies had some sense of fun and personality to them, as stupid as they were. This movie is the definition of mundane. Dr. Doom looked horrible and was an awful character. There was no one to attach yourself to throughout the movie, not even Reed RIchards. There was no weight to Doom's actions (or anyone's for that matter) or to the final battle. It's all brief, rushed and meaningless. I have to admit I liked the look of the Thing though. But overall, the special effects in this movie were pretty weak. The one thing you could expect to be decent in this day and age, and they still messed it up. I really wanted to like this movie and hoped it would be good. I loved Josh Trank's first film Chronicle, one of the best found-footage movies I've seen. Michael B. Jordan and Miles Teller are two of my favorite young actors. I usually stay away from writing bad reviews but this one I had to share.  The movie started very promising with the lives of Reed and Ben at elementary school. Since they took so long to develop Reed story, they did not have time (i guess) to show you how they developed their new acquired powers, so instead they give you a glimpse of a few training exercises. For the first 45 minutes or so of the rebooted Fantastic Four I was having a hard time seeing why there was so much negativity surrounding the movie. I admired the slowly paced set up to the characters obtaining their powers as it allowed us to get a good enough glimpse of who they are when they are just regular people. I liked that the movie aimed for a more realistic tone than the Marvel Studios movies and portrayed obtaining powers as something freaky and scary instead of "cool".

But once the four obtain their powers the movie jumps ahead a year and my emotional investment in the movie completely died. I was really looking forward to seeing how the four main characters would cope with their abilities. I wanted to see their initial horror and their slow struggle to accept who they are and to learn how to control their abilities. The movie took a cheap shortcut by fast forwarding to a point where the four had already mastered their abilities and since we missed such a vital segment of their character development I had a hard time caring about them.

The 2nd half of the movie is incredibly rushed - a stark contrast to the slow burn of the first half. "Dr. Doom" enters the scene, threatens to destroy the world and is defeated all within a timespan of 20-25 minutes at most. When the four unite against him, there is all of this talk about how they will have to put aside their differences and work as a team. Unfortunately, the movie completely failed to develop the characters and their relationships with one another. The Fantastic Four are known for being Marvel's first superhero "family", but these characters feel like acquaintances at best by the end of the film.

Speaking of the film's ending, I left the movie feeling like I had watched a 2 hour TV pilot rather than an actual movie. I just felt so unsatisfied when I left the theater, as if I had only seen a teaser for the REAL story that was bound to happen later on. We will never get that story though, as this movie is destined to bomb at the box-office and never get a sequel.

Director Josh Trank said there was a lot of studio meddling with this movie and I can believe it. It feels like a good 30 minutes were cut from the film. Maybe if the film were longer it could have addressed my complaints. But as is, the movie fails to develop the relationships between the four main characters and as a result it completely lacks heart.

People complain about origin stories and rehashing all the same angles. So Fox goes a new route with a unique twist on an awesome story. They cut out the dwelling and characters' introspective, emotional crisis' and just give you four very different young people that are brought together by a conflict. Albeit, the conflict has been done to death: Dark Knight Rises, The Flash season finale, Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer, Green Lantern, Avengers). The effects were good, the movie's pacing was well done and the origin Reed Richards was brief and informative enough to show you how far his dream took him.

His unwavering best friend lost everything in his blind allegiance to him. Johnny was a misguided youth crying out for his father's attention, while trying not to live in the shadow of his over-achieving adoptive sister, and Victor Von Doom was a man who was just rejected by the world. The woman he loved, the creation he fronted, the people he worked with and the world itself cast him aside as a social outlier. 

The sub-text is all there, and it's very well done if you're astute enough to catch it, without a director dedicating 15 minutes per character for you to establish an emotional connection. A lot of this films' context hinges on the intelligence of the one watching it, and being able to empathize while picking up details, without having a plot watered down with pointless meandering to flaunt ultimately insignificant sub-plots.

Verdict: People who are hating on the movie either don't know the characters and are starved for context, or they're just hypocrites who bitch and moan whenever they get want they asked for, because it wasn't designed just for them.

Remember, comic book movies are NOT made for comic book readers. They're adapted for casual viewers with the hopes that they do the books justice. If you read between the lines, everybody in this film was done right, arguably except for the Storm siblings, but this wasn't an emotional rollercoaster - it was a sci fi action flick. 

If you're open-minded, I'd recommend this movie.

Josh Trank's Fantastic Four is an atrociously bad film that sucks all the fun and enjoyment out of this beloved Marvel franchise.  The story follows a group of scientific researchers who work to develop a cross-dimensional teleportation device and are horribly disfigured by an industrial accident that alters their DNA.  The acting is extremely poor, and the dark and gritty tone is completely wrong for the material.  Additionally, the pacing is incredibly slow and makes the film drag on endlessly.  An abysmal re-imagining, Fantastic Four is extraordinarily dull and lifeless.

FANTASTIC FAIL....FOX just did the impossible, they make the reboot even worse than the original. I don't know where to start with this mess, this is one of the most poorly plotted movies I've ever seen.
The beginning of the film is completely rushed in order to get Reed to the Baxter Building, then a drunk Reed in a last moment decision tells Ben to came with him and Ben despite that Reed is drunk he agree to come, then the film jumps to 1 year later like we hit fast-forward in order to get to the inevitable fight between the team and Doom. There was absolutely no chemistry between the 4, Reed and Ben didn't have any sort of brotherly bond and instead it felt more like Reed just kept Ben around because he was useful, while there was zero chemistry between Reed and Sue, The family dynamic was one of the few good points about Story's Fantastic Four films. Even with script problems, you got the sense that these people really cared for each other. Another problem is that the movie is WAY too serious & dark, there is no fun at all, Fantastic 4 are not super-serious, dark and gritty, yes, they have some very serious moments but it's mostly fun, i think a combination of humorous and serious tone(serious not in high levels, only a bit) fits perfectly to F4. Inevitably i'm gonna mention how ridiculous Doom is. I'm still trying to figure out why he wanted to destroy the Fantastic 4 ? anyone know ? anyone ?...crap he was part of the group, he worked with them, why he wanted to kill them ? his motives are unclear, well his look is terrible, it looks like an unfinished look of Doom which happens in pre production, we barely saw him in the film only for 5 minutes, It's as if they were putting this movie together and then at the last minute, someone went, "Oh crap! We forgot that the Four need to fight Doom! ahh screw it, let's just bring him back right now and toss him in at the end." it's a mess...i expected the movie to be bad BUT not THAT bad, F4 just earned a place between the worst comic book movies of all time !!!!

A disappointing attempt (financially and critically) to reboot a franchise of a beloved comic series, Fantastic 4 is dull, slow, lacking any suspense and above all missing its main aim: to entertain. An initially intriguing concept is totally wasted on poor story-telling and extremely long introduction, which at one points finishes with the movie's final credits. 
The concept behind the story is actually not bad. Meant to be darker, gloomier and more thought-provoking, Fantastic 4 could have been a different summer super-hero flick. Unfortunately, something awfully goes wrong with the whole movie and the pacing, the suspense, the villain, the character - nothing meets the initial expectation and potential of the story. It is very difficult to point out what has exactly gone wrong, but the most important element is the lack of entertainment resulting from the slow pace. Basically everything that is told in 100 minutes could have been told in 50 and then a second part would have taken place (with possibly higher stakes).  
In conclusion it is only a shame that such a concept is wasted a talented young actor such as Miles Teller does not get the chance to show what he is capable of. If you are bored, have nothing to do and are willing to see even a bad superhero flick, then give Fantastic 4 a try. However, if you are more pretentious you should skip it.

Thanks to largely-negative reviews, I was expecting basically nothing from this film. Having such low expectations did make the film more enjoyable, but it was not without its problems.

Let's start with the good. The movie is very well-acted. Teller, Mara, Jordan, and Bell all did a great job as the four heroes. Each had a very different take on their character, and this really separated them from the 2005 incarnations of the characters. The relationships were done reasonably well, particularly between Reed-Ben and Sue-Johnny. I also felt that the movie didn't drag on, it got through its plot points at a non-exhausting pace.

Now for the bad. The characters seemed to do things against type. Reed separates himself from the rest of the group for some reason. Dr. Doom was underdeveloped, though memorable. The Reed-Sue dynamic was underwhelming. The editing made the film feel like it was jumping around too much.

If you were not interested in the movie to begin with, then it's a safe bet you can continue to ignore it. It is certainly a different take on a superhero film, for which I am glad. If you are curious, it's worth checking out.

The newest reboot of Fantastic Four is essentially the cinematic equivalent of ebola---it will not make you feel good at all. This isn't scrapping the bottom of the barrel, this is a barrel with the bottom ripped out. And the audience? Engulfed in a sea of aching dullness. And it's an origin story. A gifted young cast (Miles Teller, Kate Mara, Michael B. Jordan, Jamie Bell) are tasked with giving  this golden goose a fresh sheen. It's not happening.

Director Josh Trank (Chronicle), who co-wrote the mess of a script with Simon Kinberg and Jeremy Slater, take their sweet as time to get anything going. Reed Richards (Teller, slumming hard) is a science genius recruited by Dr. Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathy) to join his rogue group of scientists. Storm's adopted daughter Sue (Mara) is a willing participant, not so much his car-crazy son Johnny (Jordan). Mara and Jordan have so little to act with they pretty much give up on it as soon as the movie starts. Toby Kebbell is Victor Von Doom, Dr. Storm's hot-headed pupil, who overdoes it like crazy. You can tell he's the villain because he gives giving shit to Reed's BFF, Ben Grimm (Bell). Everyone is supposed to be excited by Reed's invention, a teleportation process that can transport a live monkey to another diminesion. How I wish I had been that monkey.

So of course the quartet get into the teleporter and voila, they're the Fantastic Four. There's nothing resembling fantastic in this trashheap. Blatant franchise building has seldom looked so cynical. That includes the lazy effects that turn Reed into the elastic Mr. Fantastic, Sue into the Invisible Woman, Johnny into the Human Torch and Ben into the pile of rocks known as The Thing. It's a pile alright. Fantastic Four is not a movie. It's an abortion. Send it to Planned Parenthood.

This movie is the first of the new Fantastic Four franchise, so (for me) it makes sense that the writers took their time to develop the story of the characters and the how they became a team. Although slow, the movie was interesting and funny. I thoroughly enjoyed it! The fight at the end was not one of the better superhero battles that I've seen, but it felt truer and more believable than your typical superhero battle. The four had never fought as a team before, and I feel this was smartly depicted. Everyone was attacking from their own angle, with their own strengths, rather than combining each other's. With this in mind, I am extremely excited for a second because the first is foundational. The relationship dynamics between the characters felt realistic, poignant, and well-developed. Moreover this review would be incomplete without me mentioning how happy I am to see not only a black leading male, but also a black superhero. I'm not going to lie, it seems to me that enough of these negative reviews come from people who were/are upset that a black male replaced a role traditionally for a white male, BUT many of these extremely popular superhero comic books were written during a period when racism was at an even higher level than it is today. Personally I feel it was an AMAZING decision. Tensions between different groups in America are increasing, as people find outlets to voice their frustrations. Seeing a minority as a superhero in a high budget movie, I do feel like the ball is moving in the right direction! 
Overall I'd encourage people to watch it, but be prepared that the action is limited as the focus seems to be on realistic development.

Fantastic 4 aims to give us a fresh take on old characters with a new tone, strong cast, and a large budget, but ultimately it fails to work as a movie altogether. The plot is confusing and lacks logic, the script is worse, and the cgi is so bad you'll think that the original fantastic 4 movies are straight from heaven. However this movie's final act is what really puts the nails straight into the coffin. Poor setup, weird and ultimately stupid action, and a villain that has no motives and looks like a pile of aluminum foil. One of the movie's other fatal flaws (one of about 50) is its tone. While it tries to be more realistic and gritty, it comes across cheesy and ... Lame. The characters have no real bond between them which is one of the main selling points of the fantastic 4. You know the "team" of the fantastic 4. This group hardly even feels like a group of friends by the end. They don't resolve the problems they have with one another, they don't have any real "bonding moments", and most of the time they are disagreeing with one another! I don't know why we're supposed to be rooting for these guys, they don't even like one another.

Overall this movies strong cast can't save it from being one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Fantastic 4 is bland, dull, and boring.

I was excited about the possibilities of a new Fantastic Four relaunch but still apprehensive about FOX behind the wheel. I took my thirteen year old son to see it yesterday so he could see my favorite comic characters from when I was a kid on the big screen. Thirty minutes into the movie my son asked me if the comic book was about a fantastic door that had four pods. I told him to hang on it wasn't just about an interdimensional door machine. To my disappointment that seemed to be exactly what the movie was about. After the 1:45 minutes of sitting through a movie about an interdimensional door I wouldn't even know this movie was about the Fantastic Four unless they has stated so in the last line of the movie. My recommendation to anyone even considering paying for this movie would be to save your money for something produced by Marvel Studios and let this Fox flop die the slow death it deserves.

It seems that close to a year ago everybody on the damn planet had already decided that another Fantastic Four movie was going to be terrible and the rights should have been sold to Marvel/Disney - the "correct" owners in the view of most.  I am quite convinced that even if Fantastic Four 2015 wasn't pretty terrible, most fanboys would have condemned it for even existing.  And that, honestly, pisses me off.  I firmly believe that every movie deserves its day in court, regardless of background or any questionable business decisions involved in making it.  But after having thoroughly examined the accused, I have no choice but to pass a guilty sentence on most counts.  

The first half is surprisingly good, being mostly well-intentioned soft science-fiction, resembling something between Interstellar and Tomorrowland.  It's actually commendable that a modern superhero film take a deliberate pace and reserve action for the final reel.  It also features an effectively creepy series of scenes where our heroes are struggling to adjust to their newfound powers/afflictions while being prodded and observed by indifferent scientists.  It's chilling PG-13 body horror, and clearly influenced by David Cronenberg.  The cinematography is impressive and the visual aesthetic and effects are a giant improvement over the cheap and campy looking two previous installments.  It's clear that director Josh Trank (an indy director who made Chronicle) wanted a complete film with these elements and wanted to avoid typical superhero tropes.  However, the second half is absolutely terrible and resembles something that was tacked on last minute.  The plot becomes forgettable and rushed.  The main villain gets shoved in 20 minutes toward the end.  The final confrontation lasts less than 3 to 5 minutes, if that.  The action is awkward and schlocky.  And worst of all - it's boring.  It also strays too far from the source material and barely resembles what a Fantastic Four movie should look like.  (There fanboys.  I threw you a bone.)  Dr. Doom has a brief, cool scene in which he murders a dozen scientists by exploding their heads, but it's fleeting.  The cast (which has received immense criticism) tried earnestly to make the most of a questionable script.  Miles Teller, Kate Mara, Michael B. Jordan, and Reg E. Cathey deserve citations of valor for courage under terrible circumstances.  The rest failed to make an impression.  

This is largely the result of 20th Century Fox hijacking the project and forcing the second half to more closely resemble the superhero movies they want to compete with.  But it was rushed and half-assed.  The strain shows and I wonder what Josh Trank's uncompromised sci-fi vision of a Fantastic Four movie would look like.  We will probably never know, and what we have here is a disaster on all fronts.  But to be fair, the reason for Fantastic Four's box office woes probably has more to do with the lack of action than its merits as a cohesive film.  Remember, audiences pay to see tons of stupid movies, as long as jokes, tits, or explosions are in order.  But Marvel Fans can rejoice, as Fox will undoubtedly sell this franchise to Marvel/Disney with only X-Men and Deadpool stubbornly resisting acquisition into the MCU.  If you have to see this, rent or stream it.  Enjoy the first half and cry yourself to sleep after watching the second.

I am assuming that no one involved in the latest version of  The Fantastic Four is planning on using this as the start of a franchise a'la X-men or Avengers. If so, they will be sorely disappointed as this was more the "Mediocre Bunch," but the blame for this goes far beyond the four principal cast members although they have to take some heat as well. 
The story is about as interesting as a nine-year-old telling an original ghost story at summer camp. Or a committee of Hollywood studio suits-which is where I think much of the blame belongs. Choose whatever trite label you wish: formulaic, predictable, cookie cutter-they all fit. There didn't seem to be an original thought in any of the narrative except for the scene showing where Ben Grimm gets his "clobberin' time" phrase.
Watching this reminded me of two other "major" dsiappointments of the past, namely Dark Man in the 90s and the 1980's enviro-feminist mess that Dino DeLaurentis made of King Kong. However, what gave those two any sort of "watchability" were the up-and-comers in lead roles: Liam Neeson in the first and Jessica Lang in the other. Even though the viewer knew the scripts were "gawdawful," the brilliance of those two actors was on display, which ironically is very evident in one piece demonstrating the "acting chops" of both at their absolute best, Rob Roy. However, I am not discussing a great movie here; I'm pointing out a weak one.
As mentioned, the cast is not fully responsible for this mess, but they are hardly blameless. In fact, other than Michael B. Jordon's performance as Johnny Storm, none of the others made any real impression other than the gum-snapping "evil corporatist," and it's pretty easy to guess what reaction the audience would have toward him. As I said: formulaic, predictable, and cookie cutter. 
Dr. Doom was Mr. Goth Gloom missing only eyeliner, clove cigarettes, or a penchant for listening to The Cure; Sue Storm was blonde-apparently her sole qualification for the part; Reed Richards, while not bad, doesn't really shine (I'll avoid the obvious pun concerning any acting abilities here).
In fact, the only thing worth sitting through during this mess was the music, so it was no surprise to see Phillip Glass's name attached to the music. However, even that is a bit depressing since he is known for being  involved in cutting edge and non-commercial work. Still, were it not for that, the single star here wouldn't even have made it.
There are two items worth mentioning: the first is that I never saw Stan Lee show up in this film (although I may have missed that), and the second is that this is the first Marvel production in a long time that had no "bonus" tease after the credits. So, perhaps the "minds" behind this knew better than to even try and pretend that this was on par with the other work coming from this studio.

This movie is bad. It's not completely terrible, but it is damn bad. The first half hour makes you believe the film has plenty of potential and starts off intriguing, but once the team gets their powers, it just leads to more build up. I swear, this entire film is just setting up for another movie and makes it feel more like a pilot episode for a TV show. However, though it is mostly build up of the characters, the chemistry between the actors is pretty strong. Once Dr. Doom does come though, the film throws a complete curveball with a random and pretty forgettable third act. Also, Doom's motivations were just ridiculous considering you never saw anything like it when he was Victor. So apart from strong chemistry and a good opening, the film just feels like a scene after scene lead up and is beat down with a pretty generic third act. I give props to all the actors, but overall it can't save the film. I definitely wouldn't recommend it but don't think it's the Batman and Robin of this decade. D+.

There had to have been a lot hands messing with Fantastic Four. I do think the movie isn't as good as it could have been and I think that's why it's so disappointing. It opens great. The cast is good and the point up to the accident that gives them their powers is good, but in the second half that Spielberg-esque sense of wonder is depleted into a rushed, mashed together film. It feels like there was a second director. Doctor Doom is introduced late as the villain and we're left with a movie that's feels like a waif. The groundwork is great actually to possibly make a great sequel that is on par with Fox's other comic book heroes, X-Men. The origin story was just a little too crammed yet a little too thin. It was defiantly battling visions as there were 3 screenwriters and rumors of editing room battles. Josh Trank can't be blamed for this movie alone. I say this was a product of battling, divorcing parents who emotionally abused their child till there was no emotion left in it. I enjoyed it more than the monstrosity that was Amazing Spider-Man 2 (which suffered with re-writes and budget cuts). I can't help but look at this movie and see the child that could have been.

So the one-massively criticized superhero flick is here, and it's been called one of the worst movies ever made, a crappy Batman & Robin, and even "Craptastic Bore", but is it really that bad? The not so Fantastic Four is defently an origin story that takes well too long to tell, and that forgets important plot details and that's well too short to be a superhero-flick and that never really pays off. 

The first act is definitely the greater aspect, with its interesting plot and somewhat exciting events. But there are also some inlogical things, especially when it comes to the editing. That lack of greatness really escalated later in the second and third act. The characters are always the major detail of every movie that needs to be well written and presented, but I'm wondering if the writers were drunk or just stupid while they were writing it, because it's just so badly done. It took the half part of the movie just to get the characters going, so it took well too long to introduce them. The second thing is that we never got to see how our heroes developed and got control over their powers. The major reason is that the editing is so terrible. They skipped everything from how they got to learn to control their powers to how their friendships and chemistry developed! They therefor missed important plot and character details. That's a serious mistake for one that just were a part of the development of the X-Men franchise, well good luck on getting back there!

That's just one small aspect with all the big mistakes in this reboot, and another one is definitely the many and serious plot-holes throughout the whole movie. The storytelling is also very messy and just weird from time to time. But the real mistake is the lack of a greater third act. We didn't get to see the wrath of the villain until like 20 minutes before the movie ended...what the hell?! Another thing is that Dr Doom is extremely vaguely presented and there are very little relatable aspects with him. He's ugly too, and you can't really feel that understanding of him, why he's the villan. The only great thing about him is that he's defently scary. So yeah, it's not a flawless movie, not by a long shot.

But it doesn't end there; The crappy Fantastic Four also got some predictable moments, and dialogs here and there, and the movie is extremely short. The major BAD thing is that there are so much plot and character story missing, but why is the movie so short then? There are even shots in the trailers that looked promising, and some of them wasn't in the movie! Im stunned by how this movie even became to be this bad. Even the climax is just too short and well too rushed for its own good. Sure it got some cool moments, but ohh myy it tries to be serious, but it totally fails due to terrible editing and storytelling; not to mention some of the vague CGI and forced humor. 

It's understandable why many out there hates it; it's full of enormous flaws. One of the most flaw-filled movie I've ever seen with its lack of plot and character details, character development, massive amount of plot-holes, messy editing, vague and non-relatable villain and of course the forced humor, rushed third act and the dry chemistry between the characters after they got their not so fantastic powers. But it got some bright aspects too; like great actors, good soundtrack and somewhat okay dialogs, but that's sometimes forced to the audience (fact-based dialogs).

Sure it got some okay aspects and you can still watch it, but the flaws are just so big and impossible to hide from. It's indeed a bad movie with it's terrible editing and lack of a Marvel-entertainment that steals the show nowadays. Give the rights back to Marvel or try again Fox!

I am definitely in the minority when I say I don't feel this movie is as bad as its rep. This movie is not good, do not misunderstand me, however if Doom was given more screen time to be fleshed out, and the big finale at the end stayed under the science-fiction/horror vibe of the first two acts, this film really could have been fantastic. There are a few silly lines in the first half of the film but besides that, it holds up very well and is a solid introduction to the movie. It does not feel like a superhero movie and funny enough, when it begins to feel that way is when it turns to shit. Watching these characters post returning to Earth and while becoming aware of their abilities, you could really see the fear and discomfort in their eyes. I really took a liking to these moments because it felt different from every other superhero origin movie we've seen. 

Then, we reach the "1 Year Later" mark. I didn't mind this idea because in many ways it worked and skipped over a lot of what we are sick of seeing from origin films. The only problem is it came too early. The audience just needed maybe another ten minutes of these frightening reveal scenes to then be satisfied with that jump in time but instead became a missed opportunity. This would have been easy to cope with if it were the only mistake. The action scenes were lackluster, also with potential to fun. When the Thing confronts Mr. Fantastic in the woods, it astounds me that there was not a big fight between these two former friends. This could have been a huge scene and instead ends within seconds of starting when the Thing head-butts Reed. It's almost like they wanted fans to get excited over the first big fight in the movie, only to realize it never comes. Then, to make matters worse, once Doom is back in the picture, the movie decides to abandon all of its originality and become an under-parred superhero movie which under this new tone loses all of its foundation. Dooms motives were interesting if only they were explained more. I liked the direction however eventually it hit a dead road. If we were able to see Doom on Planet Zero and shown him growing fond of this world and understanding why he needed to destroy Earth to be happy with it, then he would have made a fine villain. Instead, he's practically worthless and simply a villain just to be a villain. This movie is extremely frustrating because while watching, I saw so many paths it could have taken that would have benefitted the entirety of the film and instead, each time steered further and further away from where it should have been heading. This is the saddest movie flop of all time because of the never ending potential it had. I'm in love with the cast, the director, the writers, and obviously because of the X-Men have faith in the studio of Fox, so the fact that this film is hated instead of praised like its big brother franchise (X-Men) is truly heartbreaking. 
If you want to see a good Fantastic Four movie, watch this one up until they find Doom and then turn it off as quickly as possible.

Few movies have had such a prominent stink of negativity attached to them as Fox's Fantastic Four reboot, a movie that is already being considered amongst the worst superhero movies of all time. Director Josh Trank (Chronicle) was given the freedom to go darker, emphasize more science fiction, and select a cast of respected actors rather than bankable names. Then came rumors of aloof and secluded behavior on set from Trank. Then came rumors that Fox and producer/co-writer Simon Kinberg (X-Men: Days of Future Past) effectively shuttered Trank from his own movie, reshooting 40-minutes of a 90-minute film to salvage the wayward production (get ready for plenty of stuff in trailers not to be in the finished film). Not quite the room-clearing disaster of rampant speculation, the new Fantastic Four is a superhero movie that never really gets started and has constant battles with tone, characterization, and plot. It seems like the real villains of the movie are the Fox executives who signed off on the "gritty, gloomy" rendition and then interfered when they got too scared, managing to undercut the original vision, muddy an already messy film, and make things even worse. The behind-the-scenes drama is easily more interesting than anything that happens in this movie. 

Reed Richards (Miles Teller) is a science genius recruited by Dr. Storm (Reg E. Cathey). Reed invented a makeshift teleporting device as a young child with the help of his friend, Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell). At Dr. Storm's lab, Reed works with Storm's children, Sue (Kate Mara) and Johnny (Michael B. Jordan), and a morose computer programmer, Victor Von Doom (Tony Kebbell). The group transports to another dimension but is attacked by a strange green energy cloud. Victor is left behind. The surviving foursome exhibits unique abilities. Reed can stretch his body. Sue can turn invisible and create force fields. Johnny can fly and set his body on fire. Poor Ben is a hulking rock monster. Reed promises to find a way to reverse what happened to them, but the re-emergence of Dr. Doom puts the fate of the entire world at risk. 

It should be of little surprise that Fantastic Four feels like two different movies awkwardly and inarticulately smashed together. For the first hour, the movie follows the path of our heroes and their contraction of their powers. Rather than the gee-whiz fun of getting superpowers, the characters view themselves as freaks, their bodies turned against them, and their colleagues deeply afraid of them. It's a far moodier antidote to the vicarious thrills of gaining special abilities. There are some effective sequences that channel David Cronenberg's The Fly and Scanners, and it's these brief moments where you feel Trank's vision connect the most. Doom walking down a hallway and making heads explode, in a PG-13 way, is horrifying and cool. The problem for Trank, and the movie as a whole, is that this first hour still isn't a very good movie. It takes far too long for these characters to get blasted by green space goo and become supers. The setup is so protracted and needless. Did we need to see how these characters came together? Did we need to see their childhoods? It's not essential to see the team come together when we can already start from that point. In a sense, it reminded me of how needless I felt Pixar's Monsters University was; did we need to see how these colleagues became friends? Despite this action-free opening half, the screenplay could have fleshed out the four main characters to justify the added time, but it's hard for the movie to justify much. 

These are some of the most boring and underdeveloped characters in recent comic book lore. If these versions of the Fantastic Four existed in the 1960s, they wouldn't have made it to issue number two. Reed is smart. Sue is smart too but also standoffish (and adopted). Johnny likes fast cars. Ben is tough and loyal. Victor is a pessimist who called dibs on flirting with Sue. That is really about it, folks. Ben disappears for most of the film, called in to make the trans-dimensional jump because Reed feels like Ben deserves to be there since he helped create an early prototype with Reed. Actually, let's talk about that scene. It's a high school science fair yet the only other displays we see are clearly for much younger children, and yet Dr. Storm is visiting an all-ages school science fair to groom talent? That seems weird. Why does Dr. Storm offer the same offer to Ben, who helped Reed design and build his early teleporting machine? Regardless, Reed leaves his childhood pal behind with Ben's abusive family. That's because he's a good friend. Then, once the horrible transformations occur and Ben gets the worst of it, Reed runs out on him again. Sure it's in the pursuit of finding a cure, but who's to say he couldn't do that in the already constructed government super science lab? Sue doesn't even go on the first trans-dimensional voyage; it's just a boy's club. Sue spends more time in this movie staring at computer screens and looking intently than any action. It's probably for the best, though, because the scenes of her flying around in a bubble made me think of Glinda the Good Witch. I'm not a Kate Mara fan. I've found the majority of her performances to be stilted, but even I can admit she's given nothing to do here but move her eyes from the left to eh right and inform Miles Teller about Portishead, a band that's only 20-plus years old. It's sad but the most interesting part of Johnny is that a black actor, a point that caused certain more irritable fans to foam at the mouth at the adaptation, is playing him. If these super heroes aren't going to be super until halfway through the movie, they better be interesting characters. They are not even close. 

It's with the return of Dr. Doom that the movie makes its inept transition into the second movie, the one reshot by the producers and the studio. In an implausibly fast amount of time we're given our villain of the movie and he sets off to open a black hole to destroy Earth because... we're self-destructive? So humanity is self-destructive so Doom is going to destroy humanity? I would also like to know exactly how Doom survived for over a year in the alternate dimension when it clearly looks like there is nothing of substance for miles, unless green goop is edible. Did he just lose the need to go to the bathroom? Doom's powers are rather nebulous, which makes it even less interesting when the Fantastic Four decides to, get this, work together to beat the bad guy. For a movie that hasn't had one action sequence until its final act, now our characters must band together to stop Doom and his giant flashing blue light black hole thingy. The special effects are pretty undistinguished and hard to read at times. I'd also like to remark how hideously this other dimension looks. It's all rocky crags and dark clouds; it's like a less successful timeshare for the residents of Mordor. It doesn't quite look like the paradise that Doom describes it as (the brochure lied to us!). This jumbled conclusion feels so ham-fisted and rushed, a villain and a typical world-destroying fate that must be thwarted at the last minute. Things just sort of happen rather than storylines finding payoffs, and then it's all sort of over and the resolution echoes the very end of Avengers: Age of Ultron, even with the credits cutting off the vocal iteration of the title heroes. It's so transparently different in tone, sloppy in development and execution, and so quickly introduced and resolved, that the whole conclusion comes across as forcibly laughable.

At the end of watching the dire Fantastic Four reboot, I felt more sympathy for Josh Trank. He still deserves blame for helping to conceive and develop such a misshapen story and squander his actors. After three duds and whatever you want to call the 1994 Roger Corman adaptation, it feels like maybe this franchise is just cursed. Maybe these characters are too dated and their powers are too silly. Then again we know that these characters can work in the format of a movie because a good Fantastic four movie already exists, and it's called The Incredibles. It doesn't seem like anyone is going to come away completely clean from this misfire and financial flop, especially now that Trank and executives are engaging in a P.R. blame game. Fox was hoping for a rekindled franchise. Now they may be hoping to work out a deal for Marvel to buy back the rights to the characters. I would have been interested to see the full vision of what Trank was going for, especially since the one scene that feels most adamant is the best sequence in an admittedly mediocre super hero film. At least the movie would feel cohesive. It probably wouldn't be good but at least it would be committed to trying something different. Instead, the movie tries to be different from the super hero blockbusters populating the landscape and then, at the last minute, tries to follow their lead and become one of them, becoming its own misshapen and poorly developed blob. It's not the worst super hero movie in history (that honor still has to belong to the atomic bomb of taste, Batman & Robin), but even achieving sustained mediocrity is too much to expect.

Fantastic Four, (or FANT4STIC as promoted) is a film directed by Josh Trank, starring Miles Teller, Jamie Bell, Kate Mara and Michael B. Jordan as the four leading characters. Overall, we have never received a Fantastic Four film that fills the success of the comic version. From the old 80's original, to the new 2015 rehash of the franchise, there never has been a Fantastic Four film that grasps success compared to other Marvel comic book films, such as the Spiderman franchise.

I do not recommend this film, yet this recommendation is conditional. I enjoyed this film for the actors dedication, yet the dull, poor plot didn't grasp me at all. So if you are above the age of 12, and have heard of the Fantastic Four, I do not recommend this film. It is a simple way to use big comic book names, and produce a poor film, with so much hype that it's labelled as a 'Must See' from trailer reviewers who lack interest in Comic book originals.

Even as a child, I don't think I would enjoy this film, there is so much plot jump, from one point of view to the next, switching from one dull story to the next, then finally this all links into one big, dull, twist of expected, poorly written events that there was nothing that caught the eye of anyone who was there with me when we saw this film.

This film takes itself far too seriously, and as a comic book fan, who is open minded, and hopeful for all franchises and faithful to such talent such as Michael B. Jordan, I am very disappointed with this production.

It is expected now that further income for the production will be from viewers who have heard how poor this films was.

Where to even begin... So -- I believe that a majority of the reason this film received such poor reviews is because everyone is comparing it to all other marvel films, as well as the original fantastic four. If you don't compare it to anything, and just address it as a film on its own - it was slow, nothing really happened, didn't bring anything new to the genre, and had very little substance. On its own, i would give it a 57%. However, if you compare it to the other marvel movies which have set the ball as being some of the most action-packed, epic films of all time, that 57 drops to a 47% and then when you compare it with the original fantastic four, which people everywhere communally agreed never exsited, this film is actually WORSE than that one, so that drops it to a 37%. So I would give this a 37% for lack of everything. That being said -- its not as though you would watch this and cringe. There is nothing inherently bad about it. It's not a terrible film. Its just sort of pointless. One thing to keep in mind about this film is that it was really created so that Sony could keep the right to the fantastic four franchise to prevent it from reverting back to marvel and offering a competitor studio a chance at another potentially fruitful series. After having released a statement saying they plan on going ahead with a second Fantastic Four film set in this universe that will be more epic and have more action - I feel, based on this film and the characters and world they established, it has a shot at being a 70%, but I can't expect anything more than that based on the sheer lack of originality and delivery. The only thing I really liked about this film was Mr.Stretches stretchyness. They did a good job with that. Thats about it. Also; Kate Mara looks the best she ever has, but they don't really show her much.

The Fantastic Four returns to theaters in this dark and gritty reboot and the result in anything but fantastic, more in the ways of pathetic and horrendous. The Fantastic Four has had a troubled history on screen. Roger Corman produced in a film in 1994 which was never released into theaters, with the characters finding their first official on screen adventure in 2005's Fantastic Four, directed by Tim Story. Despite mixed reviews, the film was still a success at the box office and warranted a sequel entitled Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer, released in 2007. While that film received mixed reviews, slightly better than the 2005 film, it wasn't considered a box office success, causing Twentieth Century Fox to abort a third film and reboot the franchise all together. This new version arrives eight years after Rise of the Silver Surfer and ten years after the first, and the result is absolutely terrible.

This film has been known for its behind the scenes production problems, which have been highly talked about and appeared on the internet. Director Josh Trank and the studio, Fox, had a difficult relationship, while even Trank was known for being difficult to work with and erratic on set, causing various problems, including damages worth around $100,000 involving a house rented out to him.

The film focuses on Reed Richards, a high school student, who is working on a teleportation device, with help from his friend Ben Grimm. Their work attracts the attention of Professor Franklin Storm, director of the Baxter Foundation, which is funded by the government. Storm recruits Reed, who joins his adopted daughter Susan Storm to help complete a Quantum Gate, with aid from Johnny Storm, Franklin's biological son and Victor Von Doom, the creator of the Gate. After successfully testing the Gate by sending a monkey to an alternate dimension, the government decides to coordinate with Nasa by sending their own people through the Gate, forcing Reed, Johnny, Victor and a reluctant Ben to decide to carry out their own expedition. Arriving to the dimension, the group is suddenly threatened and attempts to escape, leaving Victor behind after he supposedly dies. Upon returning, the three survivors, as well as Susan, suddenly develop strange powers, prompting the government to test them. This is where the whole film goes down hill.

The film doesn't really have any real structure, who no exact pacing, while it appears like a badly put-together jigsaw puzzle with all the wrong pieces and none of the right pieces. The result is a film with no real pacing. Almost every scene seems rushed, while there is no real resolution.

The cast, sadly, doesn't do well in this film, which is a shame, since they are good actors. Miles Teller doesn't seem fit for the role of Reed and doesn't seem like a scientist. In much of the film, while he attempts to put forth scientific equations and tests, he at times feels more like an outcast. After the team develops their powers, Reed disappears, going into hiding, which doesn't really support the film or have any real merit to the plot. It just feels like it's thrown in there. Going along with Teller, Trank fought for him to be in the role, but after casting and before production, there's news that Trank and Teller developed a bad relationship, which could have effected the character and Teller's performance. Kate Mara, as Susan, is terrible, which is sad, since I have found her best performance to be in House of Cards. There is news that Fox insisted on her casting and that Trank treated her coldly as a result, possibly resulting in what we have screen. That there is really disappointing, since Mara probably could have given much more to the role and the film. Jamie Bell isn't convincing as Ben Grimm, though he handles the performance of the Thing perfectly. The same goes with Michael B. Jordan who isn't convincing as Johnny Storm and isn't given much to do with. Both Jordan and Bell are fine actors and like with Teller and Mara, it's a shame to see them not have much to do. Toby Kebbell isn't menacing or convincing as Victor Von Doom, while he doesn't prove to be a scientific genius, more like an anti-social outsider, which greatly ruins and effects the character. Tim Blake Nelson chews the scenery as government stooge Dr. Allen and Reg E. Cathey isn't interesting as mentor Franklin Storm.

A big problem with this film is the pacing. Like I said before, the film feels like a badly put-together jigsaw puzzle. There's no real structure, while it seems that the film skips the second act and goes straight to the third act, which instantly makes no sense to the viewer and to the film's story. After the team gains their powers and Reed goes into hiding, the film instantly cuts to a year later, which effects the film. Johnny, Susan and Ben have learned how to handle and use their powers, though we never see them learning how to use them. I would have liked to see them training to learn their powers, since this would have made for sense as to how later in the film they know how to control them. In Iron Man and Batman Begins, you had an origin as to Tony Stark creating the Iron Man uniform and Bruce Wayne developing the Bat-Suit, here though there is no real origin. It seems forced. Another major problem is that the team never has a real threat to face. There are reports that before production began Fox cut three key action scenes from the film, which probably one of the main reasons as to why after gaining their powers, developing them and using them, they don't face a real threat. In Iron Man, you have Tony facing off against his terrorist captors in Gulmira after he masters the Iron Man suit. In Batman Begins, Bruce takes down Carmine Falcone and starts to slowly liberate Gotham City. Here, no real threat.

Which also brings us to Dr. Doom. In the comics, Dr. Doom is a well-known villain and one of the chief adversaries of the Fantastic Four. Here, he doesn't seem like a real villain. After escaping the dimension and leaving Victor behind, since they believe him to be dead, I kept wondering where the villain was, how was he plotting his return. When Nelson's character sends a small group back to the dimension after Reed fixes the Gate, they find Doom and the film is almost over, a major problem I also had with Hugh Laurie's so-called villainous character in Tomorrowland. Here, sadly, Doom isn't a real threat, he's underused. Even Tim Blake Nelson isn't a real threat, he's more like a scenery chewing villain. Sure he wants to use the Fantastic Four as government weapons and take over the alternate dimension, but still there's no real motivation. The same with Dr. Doom, which is a problem. In The Dark Knight, the Joker's motivation is clear: he wants to cause chaos, destroy Gotham and bend Batman to his will. Even if Skyfall, Javier Bardem's Silva wants to kill M and gain revenge. Here, Doom has no real motivation. Doom isn't even a danger to the team.

The team also doesn't seem like a real team. They don't seem like the Fantastic Four. All of a sudden, after Doom's appearance and threat, do they manage to work together and trust each other. Up until than, not so much. Once again, it would have seemed better for the team to get know each other, their powers and how to work together. Here, it seems forced.

While the special effects in the film are fine, especially with the Thing, Reed, Johnny and Susan, the ones for Doom are not. It seems that toward the end, the studio came to the point where they felt they developed good effects for the other characters, but didn't need to for Doom. Here it's a shame. Doom doesn't look interesting. He seems more like a crash-test dummy thrown into acid, more like a joke.

The other problem with the film is that it is also too dark. This is a problem, since every comic book movie doesn't need to be dark, gritty and grounded. While it worked with Christopher Nolan's Batman trilogy and even several films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, it didn't really work with the Spider-Man reboot, The Amazing Spider-Man and The Amazing Spider-Man 2. It's almost as if some filmmakers have started to think that if Nolan could darken Batman and ground him and make him gritty, other comic book films can do the same. Not so much. The gritty and bleak feel ruins Fantastic Four. It would have worked better if this film was lighter and more colorful, more like Sam Raimi's Spider-Man.

Marco Beltrami and Philip Glass try their best with the score, but seem to be underused at times, which is also a shame, considering that they are great composers.

The end result is a film that seems to be made by committee, by a bunch of board members sitting in a room and throwing out ideas. While we can blame Fox for interfering with the director, we should also probably blame Trank. While he claims that his version would have been better had Fox not interfered, the big question is: How would had it been better? 

What Fox needs to do is give this property back to Marvel, who will probably make a way better film, or else choose a director that they can trust and work well on this kind of film. The film isn't fantastic, it's pathetic. Terrible. Horrendous.

The only good thing is that it's 100 minutes long and when the credits appear, you are pleased that it's over, despite wasting 100 minutes of your life on a real clunker. This one is a real mess and will probably stand as the worst comic book film, worst than Batman and Robin, while it also makes 2005's Fantastic Four appears much better and a lot like art. Which isn't saying much honestly. Pass on this film and see a better comic book film.

Marvel is going be one of the best studios to transform their comics into films, that is actually perfected well. Their recent slew of movies based on their properties has been well received amongst both critics and audiences alike. Until now. With the release of "Fantastic Four", the studio has stumbled upon a major dud, and might set the company back for a little while. The film itself is bad film, but it is definitely not the worst movie Marvel has released. There is potential here, we're just not seeing it. "Fantastic Four" is a perfect example of letting a studio take over the production, and supplying the needs and wants of the fans. And ultimately, it just comes out as one big mess.

The plot involves four young minds working on a way to teleport towards another dimension. Unfortunately, a freak accident causes the quartet to gain supernatural powers. These include Reed Richards (Miles Teller) developing elasticity throughout his entire body. Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan) setting his entire body on fire. Sue Storm (Kate Mara) can turn invisible and create forcefields. And Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell) whose whole body has been transformed into a piece of solid rock. Can the four of them work together, or will their personal issues get in the way?

Oh, boy. "Fantastic Four" is a bad movie. To begin with, the special effects look nice, but it feels like everything is fake, especially with Bell's Thing; whenever the character is on screen, all the audience sees is just a computer generated image walking around. It defeats the illusion of what we're seeing isn't always there. The sets, again, look nice, but everything is done in the computer, it makes the audience wonder why the filmmakers didn't bother with building actual sets that looked real enough to make the audience think it is believable. It just feels cheap and unnecessary. The editing is another big issue as everything (except for the first third), feels absolutely rushed, and makes the whole production feel predictable.

But the biggest issue that the movie has going for it is the writing. There are various plot threads that feel left out, and could have been explored a bit further. The team gets their powers way too easily; we get the traditional training montage of the team using their powers, and we've seen it done before. Along with the terrible editing, the writing plays a role in this traditional formula by expanding the timeline of events happening in the movie with no regards with what is going on. This happens, and this happens; it's just formulaic.

Now, with that being said, is there anything good about the movie? Well, the cast does a good job in their roles, and their direction by Josh Trank isn't bad. Plus, the orchestrated score does a nice job setting the tone of the film. But other than that, the film just suffers from the aforementioned problems.

In conclusion, "Fantastic Four" could have easily been given another chance, had the production actually spent some time in the editing room and doing what they want, instead of what we got in its place. Overall, this is is just a fantastic mess.

As an avid comic book reader, I was never fond of the Fantastic Four (established 1961), sure they have some compelling space story lines, but I always felt they worked better in a larger spectrum with other Marvel characters (in the comics). Whether it is Reed geeking out with his other science bros like Tony Stark (Iron Man), Dr Hank Pym (Ant Man) & Peter Parker (Spider-Man) or when the Thing takes (or at least tries) on the Hulk or Invisible Woman/ Sue Storm aka Sue Richards having an undeniable chemistry with Namor (Marvels version of Aquaman) or Logan (Wolverine), this four characters (including Johny Storm aka Human Torch) just together living as a family never really interested me much. Well except for the exception of their main antagonist Dr Doom (IGN ranked him as #4 on best villains of all time). But yet as a huge fan of the super hero genre, it is disappointing to see how despite millions of fans (& story lines),  the Fantastic Four have never seen a good Big screen adaptation. There was a movie in 1994 made by Roger Corman (king of the B-Movies), which was never released. It was only made to secure rights for a friend, and is stuff of pure cinema legend and sought out by cult film fanatics. If you've seen any YouTube clips of it, you know it's terrible (Update: the movie has found its way online). Let's fast forward to 2005, where the guy who made the 'Barbershop' movies director Tim Story was given the opportunity to make a 'Fantastic Four' movie. If you can recall it, you'd remember it was pretty enjoyable yet, Jessica Alba was really the only memorable thing from the movies, or at least the most talked about. Nevertheless, the film was a box office success enough to guarantee a 2007 sequel 'Fantastic 4: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)' which was pretty awful.  'Fantastic Four' is one of those Marvel properties that has yet to be turned over to Marvel itself, and is still owned by 20th Century Fox, which is unfortunate, because that studio still has no clue what it's doing with this franchise. That brings us up to date with 2015's reboot directed by Josh Trank. Trank's only other credit was the awesome "found footage" superhero film 'Chronicle', but supposedly Trank is very difficult to work with, which is why he was booted off the upcoming 'Star Wars' film. Whatever good 'Chronicle' had going for it is non-existent here with 'Fantastic Four' and seems like it's one long set up for something yet to come. Right from the production & the casting (controversial casting of Michael B Jordan, an African American actor in an essential white role), the film has been making news for all the wrong reasons. I think the first major clue for me that this movie was doomed (no pun intended) was, the 1st trailer itself! A super hero film trailer which was not exciting! Even duds like Elektra & Ghost Rider had better looking trailers. Another major clue for me that this movie was doomed was its running time of 100 minutes. Why? Because when you have a film like this - a reboot, where it has to introduce various new characters, set them up and a new premise/universe, the movie isn't going to be an hour and a half long. It's going to be two hours. Those extra twenty- thirty minutes can make a difference. For the record, the first two Fantastic Four movies had around the same running time. The original film was only six minutes longer. But that movie wasn't the best one, either. I reminded myself of X-Men. X-Men was a great movie. It had a similar running time, but not the same task, as it wasn't a reboot, well kinda. Yet as the first installment in a franchise, it did a fantastic job at setting things up. Yet, with Josh Trank at the helm & a talented cast of Miles Teller (who was awesome in Whiplash last year), Kate Mara (exceptional in Netflix' House of Cards), Michael B Jordan (brilliant in Fruitvale Station) & Jamie Bell (excellent in TURN: Washington's Spies), I wanted to give this film a chance despite the wide spread negative reviews pounding the internet. In my opinion, its not as bad as the reviews are pointing it out to be, in the sense its not 'the worst superhero film', like common did everyone forget Batman & Robin, Elektra, Hulk, Iron Man 2 & Catwoman? This is a film very much out of time and place in today's market of superhero movies. Ten or fifteen years ago a studio might have been able to get away with it but not today. Audiences like to be entertained and with the competition offering much more excitement, I don't see audiences taking to this, at all.  The film's plot really potential & it does manage to have some great moments, but it just takes too much time to become interesting, long enough to make us not care. The story follows young genius, Reed Richards, who at the beginning of the film, working on an experiment that attempts to construct a teleportation device. It was hardly a success as the object they've sent to who-knows-where, never returned. Seven years later, now teenage Reed (Miles Teller) is again trying his luck on the same experiment. The attempt yields a better result but is still dismissed as a magic trick by his high school teacher, but not by Dr. Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathey), who at that moment, is drawn with utter interest to Richard's experiments. The meeting brings Richard's feet to Baxter Institute where he is joined by Storm's adopted daughter, Sue (Kate Mara), his son, Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), and his ex protegee Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell), to work in completing a larger and more advanced version of Richard's device. The success of their effort prompts their team to send all of them four to their target alternate universe, but the consequence is far worse than they could imagine. It's easy to dismiss Trank's Fantastic Four as an unfortunate victim of superhero fatigue that emerges in the wake of the continuous influx of superhero movies inundating the big screen, but you can't shrug off its fatal narrative flaws that include unfocused pace and bland character developments. The latter may have been completely covered by the actors playing the two-dimensional characters, but ex-positional defects keep sending them to becoming something the audience might find hard to care about. Perhaps its the ill-contrived rationales behind how all the often-sense-deprived proceedings work, that keeps the film constructing a form, worth-of- attention, or the forced CGI-gimmicks that strip the sense off the moment's supposedly strong sentiments, that hampers its spectators' ability to absorb its message, and thus, feel that the dangers these characters are about to face, is real. Either way, it's difficult to care, much less find reasons why we still should. The running time really is a problem. This film is rushed beyond belief and its plot is nonsensical. The characters' introductions are decent enough, particularly the Fantastic Four, but their roles throughout the rest of the film are disconcerted. Exposition can be tiring, but after the exposition ended and the action was supposed to pick up - it didn't. Second, the plot. As I said above, the film's plot seemed interesting. It had potential and it looked like it could go somewhere, especially considering how superhero movies nowadays have managed to flesh out their stories and make them very enjoyable. There are even hints at awesome things to come at certain points. But the film's in shambles. You hope and feel it will go somewhere, but in its hour and a half running time, it feels so empty. One of the reasons for that is the third thing, the writing. The writing isn't good - the film's climactic conflict feels backed up into the end of the movie, because there wasn't enough time to set it up. The writing caused the pacing to be terrible - transitions between scenes weren't good and some scenes either went on for too long or were far too short. Speaking of "things", The Thing is entirely CGI. No make-up, costume or anything - just a giant, naked rock monster. Yes, he's naked, too. Not even any shorts. Huh. But yet, in his shortest screen time, he will probably be the only thing you remember. Did I talk about Doom? I don't get it why cant FOX just stick to his comic book origins? It may sound a bit flashy, but its anything better than what they have been providing us with. Sure the Doom here is way more efficient & creepy than the previous films, but what is with him being this dis grunted blogger, & shouldn't they have mentioned he is going to appear on screen for only five minutes or so. Doom makes an unsurprising return here as their common enemy, driven by a fusion of body and alien matter to cause global destruction and around whose defeat to ensure the survival of planet Earth becomes a rallying call for the team to unite despite their differences. It is one of the dullest and most unexciting finales we've seen in a Marvel movie, not least for the fact that it doesn't know how to collectively bring together their superpowers except in a tag-team fashion to distract their opponent. There's probably some salvageable remnants left in Fox's previous attempts to bring one of Marvel's most popular superhero team to the big screen. That's maybe what Fox thinks in pushing this new adaptation, given how franchises keep being rebooted and resurrected these days, assuming either lighter or darker takes, to pull away themselves from the shadows of their previous (most often, forgettable) forms. The latter is more evident with this film, as Director Josh Trank, puts a darker spin to it, employing a grittier feel to its plot. While that is true and recognizable, there's no denying of its desperate efforts to emulate its Marvel predecessors. Trank's intention of emphasizing the tension within the quartet is evident and admirable, but is ultimately undone by a script that doesn't develop it in any substantive manner. Worse still, it leaves an audience looking for visual spectacle severely wanting, that not even a very busy third act manages to salvage. The way the characters get their powers is more interesting and more realistic, and the team is assembled, but they skip any kind of training montage to a single display of their abilities which are not yet honed, we skip all that to introduce the main villain. He is majorly overpowered for reasons unknown, but the action finally begins, only for the movie to end after the first and only super showdown. On the whole, 'Fantastic Four' is a not so fantastic effort to build a franchise! Despite a likeable cast, a weak story,  a cringe worthy script & average special effects, the film turns out to be one of the most disappointing films I have seen all year. To be honest I was really enjoying the movie until the end and it straight up didn't deliver after making us get to know these characters, and making us wait to see the good stuff! I don't think this 'franchise' needs to crossover into any other universe, be it preferably Marvel and not X-Men, as it's got enough potential to hold it's own, and I'd give a sequel a chance because it's a step in the right direction, which is still scheduled for a release on June 2017.

Normally I write a small introduction and a small synopsis, but with this film I will omit that as I have a lot to say about this. Let's start with the controversies/geek problems: Johnny Storm is African-American? Irrelevant, Michael B. Jordan is a good actor. It is not a faithful adaptation of the source material? As far as I understand this closely follows the Ultimate Version. Josh Trank is a problematic director? Bryan Singer had those problems in the first "X-Men" film and everyone loves that. They disrespect these "iconic" characters? Honestly this super team is extremely silly and dated due to their 60s origins, and even Marvel killed the F4 comic books as they are so focused in their CU (that is truly a disrespectful move to fans). This looks like the worst super hero film of recent years? Have you seen "Daredevil", "Elektra", "Thor", "Thor: The Dark World", "X-Men Origins Wolverine", and "The Incredible Hulk"?! A comic book film is supposed to be comedic and colorful? The best super hero trilogy - "The Dark Knight Trilogy"- is dark and sophisticated; it is not a bad thing to go to this direction, just because it isn't made by Marvel Studios that doesn't mean is awful, but of course it depends on the execution. Is this the worst super hero film of all time? It isn't worse than "Superman IV", "Batman & Robin", or the examples named earlier. It is the worst Fantastic Four film? Have you seen those last three films?! There is nothing lower than that. 
With all that being said, "Fantastic Four" is a mess. It is horribly edited, the CGI is horrible (I haven't seen CGI this bad in a summer blockbuster since "X-Men Origins"), the characters are underdeveloped, the villain is laughable, the second half is dreadful, a rushed and laughably incoherent ending, and it is incredibly short for a comic book film. But even if it suffers from those colossal problems due to the creative issues and the problematic production, this isn't the abomination people claim it is (a lower score than "Quest for Peace", "Pixels", "Jupiter Ascending", and "Howard the Duck"? You got to be kidding me). The first half of this film had potential as it has character development, the cast deliver the best performances they could (with the exception being the not so well utilized Kate Mara), some of the imagery is good, the "Chronicle" style works perfectly with this characters, and there is even a scene that tries to emulate Cronenberg´s body horror. 
"Fantastic Four" is a bad movie, no doubt about it, but it isn't an abomination. It had some potential in the first half but then it all disappeared. Don't pay attention to the RT score or most of the audience reviews, as they are Marvel fan boys who hate every non Marvel comic book film. A bad film that had potential of being a solid film but the result was this mess of film.

If I had left halfway through this, I'd be giving a much better score. As far as "origin stories" go in the world of comic book movies, Josh Trank's take on the "Fantastic Four" had the novel approach of viewing their powers through the lens of a horror movie. Indeed, the body horror element and the gritty level of realness that Trank brought to this film made it something special... right up until the second half kicks in and then suddenly you have no idea what direction it wants to go. Not to delve too much into the backstage drama that this film went through, but you can't help but wonder who's to blame for squandering such a fresh spin on a superhero property - a meddling studio, or an indecisive director? There were definitely pieces of a good (and probably great) movie in here. It's just that you can see all the glue that is loosely pinning the bad bits onto the good bits. Not only was the movie rewritten and reshot DURING filming, but entire scenes and set pieces that were already shot were dumped in favour of the studio's vision for a better movie. Which is a real shame! The first half was sooooo decent, I thought. It's not the worst movie of all time (as some blind haters will have you believe), but I just can't tell anyone to go see this for themselves if they're paying for it. This is only worth seeing if you're curious what a big budget car crash looks like, or if you're just genuinely curiously (like I was). Again, it's not terrible... but it's just not good either.

Fantastic Four (2015) is the reboot of the comic book franchise. It is about a group of teenagers who gain powers and changes them physically after they visit a different dimension. The previous incarnations of the comic book were a little too campy and ended up not being so great. This version isn't much better. I will say this though: it is definitely less campy and the first hour actually isn't too bad. It's the 2nd half that brings it way down. The payoff for all the set up is terrible. After getting their powers, the movie jumps forward a year so we don't see them develop at all. The 2nd act gets kind of boring and then the final act is too rushed and Dr. Doom is horrible. He reappears too quickly and the final fight starts and ends too quickly. For these reasons, I can only give it a 2/5.
